column1: This course deepens the data analysis expertise which students have gained in prior studies or preparatory trainings. The focus is on some of the most commonly used methods of data analysis in the social sciences in general and the field of media and communication in particular. Half of the course will therefore focus on quantitative methods of data-analysis (such as T-tests, Anova, factor, and regression analysis), while the other half will focus on qualitative methods (such as thematic analysis, discourse analysis and visual analysis). While part of each meeting will be devoted to theoretically exploring a method, ample time will be spent on practicing methods.

</style>
• common methods of both quantitative and qualitative data analysis in media and communication;
• strengths and weaknesses of each discussed method of analysis.
• choose the method of analysis that best fits their research design;
• apply the covered methods when analyzing media content, processes, uses, and influences;
• report their analyses in oral and written form.

column1: The Master thesis including the thesis proposal constitutes the heart of the master programme MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration and relate and link their insights with managerial insights and relevance. The thesis is perceived as a proof of their academic level of thinking, especially a proof of analytical craftsmanship combined with problem-solving and critical reflection. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analysis and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

By choosing a research topic in a profile students express their special interest and affinity towards a future employer. The thesis trajectory is considered as the main opportunity to bring in a focus in the program and express one’s affinity towards managerial challenges in a field in business administration. The topics as offered for a thesis cover the main domains in business administration, e.g. marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. MiM students are always required to consider and discuss elaborately the relevance and implications for management.  The title of the thesis will be mentioned on the grade list. Therefore, it is recommended to choose a title wisely to indicate one’s interests.  The thesis is written under the supervision of a coach and a co-reader.   Before working on the thesis a research proposal (or: thesis proposal) has to be crafted.

column1: This course forms an introduction to the fascinating domain of microbes, i.e. the organisms (or entities', such as viruses and prions) that cannot be observed with the naked eye, but have a profound influence on the existence of life on Earth. You will get acquainted with the vast and varied microbiological world and will learn that life can appear in many shapes and forms, and can sometimes tolerate the harshest conditions. Clearly, the saying 'everything is everywhere, but the environment selects' by Dutch botanist and microbiologist Baas Becking (1895-1963) is one of the crucial take-home messages of this course. Apart from the general concepts of microbiology, the course will also zoom in on the world of pathogens: the microorganism that can cause disease. General concepts of infectious diseases will be discussed, and pandemics (worldwide epidemics) from the past will be taken as examples of the devastating outcome that certain infections can have on a population. In addition to studying microorganisms, a major part of this course will be devoted to the human immune system, i.e. the molecular and cellular 'system' that is aimed at recognizing and eliminating harmful microbiological intruders in our body. The different constituents of the immune system will be studied, and their role in the battle between pathogens and host will be explained. Finally, we will discuss the therapeutic options that exist in case the immune system fails to eliminate a pathogen from the human body. The mechanisms of action of the various groups of antibacterial (antibiotics) and antiviral drugs will be studied, as well as the role of vaccination in reducing disease burden.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Identify and describe the general characteristics of prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and unicellular (eukaryotic) parasites;
• Understand the evolution of life and the role of photosynthetic bacteria in creating the Earth's atmosphere;
• Explain bacterial metabolism and recognize what is an autotroph or an heterotroph
• Describe viral replication mechanisms;
• Recognize human pathogens: prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and protozoan parasites;
• Understand the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system and immune disorders;
• Recognize (emerging) infectious diseases and the interplay between pathogen and host;
• Identify and characterize sexually transmitted diseases (chlamydia, gonorrhea, syfilis, genital herpes and human papilloma viruses);
• Explain zoonoses and pandemics (Yersinia pestis (black death), influenza (Spanish flu) and AIDS);
• Understand diagnostics of infectious diseases;
• Explain antiviral and -bacterial drugs and vaccination, and the mechanism of antiviral and -bacterial resistance.

column1: Na een algemene inleiding in de micro-economie zal de aandacht uitgaan naar de keuzetheorie. Uitgangspunt is dat economische handelingen doelgericht zijn: de beperkte middelen die een subject voorhanden heeft worden zodanig gebruikt dat een bepaalde doelstelling bereikt wordt. Dit algemene uitgangspunt wordt op de handelingen van de consument en producent toegepast. Vervolgens komt het functioneren van markten aan de orde. Ook wordt een begin gemaakt met het analyseren van strategische interactie met behulp van de speltheorie.</body>

column1: This course will provide the basic tools and training in microeconomics. It begins with the study of consumer behaviour and how their choices form the basis of demand in an economy. Firm behaviour is studied next to understand the input-output decisions of firms and to see where supply comes from. The third part brings together both sides of the economy and different market structures are discussed. Finally, strategic interaction between economic agents is the topic of the last part. Throughout, applications are provided to help understand why economic theory can be used to study behaviour in the real world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • To understand how consumer choice forms the basis for individual demand, and how individual demand translates into market demand.
• To understand the role of information in decision making.
• To understand how firms decide what and how much (output) to produce, and how they decide which resources (inputs) to use for production.
• To understand the concept of a perfectly competitive market.
• To understand what it means for a firm to have extreme market power.
• To understand that in the real world a whole spectrum of market structures exists between the extremes of perfect competition and monopoly.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The first part of the course deals with the theory of the consumer. Topics covered include consumer choice under certainty and uncertainty, and individual and market demand;
• The second part focuses on the theory of the firm, and includes the topics of firm production and firm cost;

• The last part of the course turns to market structures (monopoly, imperfect competition and perfect competition), to the joint analysis of firm and consumer behavior within a market (general equilibrium theory) and to factor markets (especially labor).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

De middeleeuwen beginnen wanneer West-Europa in economisch en cultureel opzicht tot een primitief stadium terugvalt. Eerst rond 800 trad in de kloosterscholen een voorzichtig herstel van de wetenschappen en de wijsbegeerte op. Daar doceerde men een neoplatonisme, dat men onder meer via Augustinus kende. In de twaalfde eeuw ontstaan de eerste universiteiten, waar de wijsbegeerte van Aristoteles de grondslag van het onderwijs vormt. Dit was mogelijk doordat de hele Aristoteles onder meer door vertalingen vanuit het Arabisch wordt herontdekt. Vanaf dat moment oefent zij bijna een half millennium een ‘despotisch’ gezag uit over de geesten. In de cursus zal worden stilgestaan bij de vernieuwingen met name in de metafysica en de kentheorie, die ondanks de conserverende werking van het ‘schoolse’ onderwijs aan de universiteiten plaatsvonden.

De Renaissance wordt - de naam zegt het al - gekenmerkt door de wedergeboorte van de klassieke cultuur. Deze werd mogelijk door het humanisme: het ontstaan van het hermeneutisch probleem. In de filosofie betekende dat de aandacht voor andere vormen van klassiek denken dan Aristoteles. Uit de herleving van het platonisme en het scepticisme komt ook iets nieuws voort: de moderne natuurwetenschap, die in Francis Bacon haar eerste programmatische pleitbezorger vindt. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de zogenaamde ‘pyrrhonistische crisis’ die in de tweede helft van de zestiende eeuw haar eerste woordvoerder vindt in Montaigne.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Overzicht van de verdere ontwikkeling van de filosofie vanaf de oudheid. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen religieuze en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan in het interpreteren van een filosofische tekst uit de middeleeuwen en zich vertrouwd gemaakt met de historische wijsgerige terminologie.</body>

column1: The Middle East has been at the centre of world attention for over a century, as well as an object of widespread misconceptions. This introductory course allows you to gain an understanding of contemporary politics of the Middle East. The course is designed for students with limited or no prior knowledge about the region but will also challenge those with previous exposure to the Middle East.

Combining comparative politics and area studies approaches, this course will begin by familiarising you with the dynamics that played a pivotal part during the emergence of the modern state system at the end of World War I. Historical, ideological and economic forces will be highlighted that continue to shape political realities today.

Questions prompted by the uprisings of 2011 represent a major theme throughout the course. Why does authoritarianism seemingly hold sway in the region, and how does this relate to democracy? How are identity and politics connected, and how is resistance to power structured? How do transnational dynamics, socio-economic conditions or ethno-religious diversity affect politics?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • identify and comprehend major themes in Middle East Politics
• demonstrate insight in historical dynamics and current developments
• locate and explain sources of tension and conflict in the region

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85564,2019,Migratie en Diversiteit: governance in de multicuturele samenleving,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['BJ van der Ent - van den Berg, MSc', 'dr. FG Snel', 'dr. I van Breugel', 'dr. M van der Linden', 'dr. M van Houte, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De minor Migratie en Diversiteit biedt verdiepend inzicht in governance-vraagstukken rondom migratie en de etnisch-diverse, multiculturele samenleving. De minor maakt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief een analyse van de aard en omvang van internationale migratie, dominante verklaringen voor migratie, en de betekenis van migratie en diversiteit voor de ontvangende samenleving in het algemeen en voor governance-vraagstukken in het bijzonder (integratie- en immigratiebeleid, stedelijk beleid, enz.). Indien nodig worden ook uitstapjes gemaakt naar andere disciplines (economie, geschiedenis, recht). Centrale thema’s in de minor zijn:

column2: • Historische schets van de voornaamste migratiepatronen en migrantengroepen in Nederland en in West-Europa.
• De betekenis van migratie voor de samenleving; hoe hebben deze migrantengroepen de Nederlandse samenleving veranderd?
• Welke governance vraagstukken spelen op dit vlak op lokaal, nationaal en Europees niveau.
• Verklaringen van internationale migratie vanuit diverse sociaalwetenschappelijke disciplines.
• De beheersing van migratiestromen: grenscontroles, detentie, uitzetting, ‘zelfstandige terugkeer’.
• De (zowel positieve als negatieve) gevolgen van etnische diversiteit of “superdiversiteit” voor steden en hoe steden daar in praktijk mee omgaan.
• Theoretische modellen van migratie- en integratiebeleid (republikanisme, multiculturalisme, differentialisme en assimilationisme)

• Afstemming van beleid t.a.v. migranten en diversiteit op verschillende bestuursniveau’s: lokaal, nationaal, Europees (het vraagstuk van ‘multi-level governance’ toegepast op migratie- en integratievraagstukken).

column1: De minor stelt studenten vanuit meerdere opleidingen in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • heeft kennis van migratiepatronen van nu en uit het verleden, en heeft begrip van de oorzaken en gevolgen ervan.
• heeft kennis van de feitelijke ontwikkeling van diversiteit in de Nederlandse samenleving;
• heeft kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische perspectieven op migratie- en integratieprocessen;
• kan uitleggen hoe migratie en diversiteit tot transformaties hebben geleid in de moderne samenleving;
• heeft kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische perspectieven op de governance van integratie en migratie, en kan deze empirisch toepassen;
• kan een analyse maken van verschillen in beleid tussen landen en tussen diverse beleidsniveaus (Europees, nationaal, lokaal).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87874,2019,Migratie en participatie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. L van Kalken', 'mr. SPM Wolf', 'prof.mr. R de Lange']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus wordt aandacht besteed aan beginselen van migratierecht, met bijzondere aandacht voor integratievraagstukken en burgerschap. Het migratierecht is een complex terrein met veel bijzondere regelingen, niet alleen op nationaal niveau (Vreemdelingenwet c.a.) maar ook op internationaal niveau (EU-migratierecht, Vluchtelingenverdrag, EVRM, c.a.). Een bijzondere vorm van regeling van migratieprocessen is het vrij verkeer van personen tussen de lidstaten van de Europese Unie, en de ontwikkeling van het idee van Europees burgerschap. Ook binnen Nederland staan migratie- en integratievraagstukken deels in het teken van ideeën over burgerschap. In het vak Migratie en participatie komen vragen aan de orde rond inburgering, maar ook rond bredere juridische aspecten van de ‘migratiecrisis’.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Doel van dit vak is het verkrijgen van inzicht in de hoofdzaken van het migratierecht, met bijzondere aandacht voor integratievraagstukken en burgerschap.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88269,2019,Migratie, diversiteit en criminaliteit",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['drs. E Jaspers', 'drs. SS Nabi, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Internationale migratie gaat van oudsher samen met regulering, uitsluiting en restricties. Het zijn processen die zich vooral, maar niet uitsluitend in urbane gebieden manifesteren. Ook wordt migratie al heel lang met criminaliteit in verband gebracht. Door diverse vormen van migratie en de positie en integratie van migranten in m.n. Nederland en Europa centraal te stellen, willen wij in dit vak criminologische en juridische kennis toepassen op een actueel maatschappelijk onderwerp. Thema’s die hierbij aan de orde komen zijn het criminologische taboe op etniciteit; (ir)reguliere migratie en het toezicht op en de beheersing van migratiebewegingen; migratie gerelateerde criminaliteit als mensensmokkel en mensenhandel; de constructie van het ‘integratieprobleem’; racisme, radicalisering en extremisme; beschrijvingen en verklaringen van ‘allochtone’ criminaliteit; de constructie van het ‘illegalenprobleem’, bestaansstrategieën van onrechtmatig verblijvende vreemdelingen, vreemdelingenbewaring, uitzetting en terugkeer. Je verwerft tijdens het vak niet alleen inhoudelijke kennis op deze terreinen, maar maakt ook kennis met de bedoelde en onbedoelde effecten van het Nederlandse en Europese beleid op deze terreinen waardoor je na afloop kunt reflecteren op deze actuele migratie gerelateerde vraagstukken.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Globalization, understood as the massive increase in flows of goods, services, ideas and people across borders and the widening and deepening of global interconnectedness and interdependence between places, is without a doubt among the most profound societal transformations of the last centuries. By definition, globalization is a transnational, boundary-crossing process that depends on the mobility of not only capital, but also labor. Technological and technical advances have created communication and transportation networks that allow for unprecedented levels of human mobility for transnational elites. Yet, paradoxically, the situation of refugees and ‘undesirable’ migrants is characterized by immobility despite these advances. We will therefore investigate how (im-)mobility is produced, experienced and governed in a globalized world.

In this course, we explore the intricate and complex relationship between globalization and migration in further detail. We draw on insights from the sociological literature on globalization to grasp how global migration brings about changes in various spheres of social life. First, we review sociological theories on the meaning of ‘globalization’ as a process of societal transformation. Next, we investigate the effects globalization has had on the scale, composition and dynamics of migration patterns and, vice versa, how migration has facilitated global change. In the remaining sessions, we further dissect and examine the relationship between globalization and migration by zooming in on its economic, cultural, political and social dimensions.

Throughout, we learn to consider how globalization at times operates as a force of universalization and homogenization and, at other times, as a force of polarization and heterogenization. Globalization can lead to the formation of integrated labour markets, cosmopolitan cultures and transnational social ties, but it can also give rise to global inequality, localism and right-wing populism. Both the ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ of globalization are considered in this course, ranging from hyper-mobile transnational elites to immobilized undocumented workers. Rather than solely conceiving of globalization in trans- and supranational terms, we will also explicitly investigate how globalization manifests itself at the local level.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Discuss theories and empirical research on globalization and migration
• Analyse the impact of globalization on global migration patterns and vice versa
• Summarize and present theories and the results of scientific studies on the economic, cultural, political and social aspects of globalization
• Apply theoretical insights from the globalization literature to a case study on or ongoing debate around migration
• Research and write a paper about a subdimension of globalization and its impact on migration

column1: International migration traditionally goes hand in hand with regulation, exclusion and restrictions. Migration has also been associated with crime for a very long time. International migration traditionally goes hand in hand with regulation, exclusion and restrictions. Migration has also been associated with crime for a very long time. In this course we will focus on various forms of migration and the divergent incorporation processes of migrants, with a special European and Dutch perspective. In doing so we will apply criminological and legal knowledge to this topical academic and socially relevant issue. Themes addressed are: ethnicity as a taboo in criminology?; race and migration as classical themes in criminology; explaining (ir)irregular migration movements; different faces of migration control; human smuggling and human trafficking; the social construction of an ‘integration problem’ and the integration paradox; the nexus between social exclusion, racism, radicalisation and extremism; explanations of higher crime rates amongst some migrant groups; the social construction of the so-called 'illegals problem'; coping strategies of foreigners without legal documentation; immigration detention, deportation and return.
<body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able:

column2: • Students have knowledge and insight into the history and contemporary reality of migration flows that will differ in legal status and migration motives, incorporation of immigrants in receiving countries, processes of radicalisation and involvement in crime that is related to someone’s immigration background,
• Students have insight into and can critically reflect on everyday problems of multicultural societies, relating these problems to criminological debates and policy developments,
• Students understand and can critically reflect on the stratification of migration processes, including undesirable side-effects of restrictive migration policies.

column1: In this course we take a ‘bottom-up’ approach to social groups that adjust their cultural/religious traditions in order to deal with rapid change in the context of mobility, both in terms of urban or transnational migration and social mobility. These transformation processes occur in a diversity of historical and geographic contexts and are all constituted by materiality causing the emergence of new ‘economies of cultural value’. These new flows of materialities impact both the host societies and those ‘back home’ creating new topographies of meaning and spaces of heritage. How have mobile/migrant communities bestowed religious and cultural meaning on material assets such as meat, money and material items, like halal meat, Islamic banking and the keffiyeh, the  Palestinian shawl? In what way are notions of gender, ethnicity, race and class intersected with materiality thus marking cultural/religious group boundaries in a ‘modern’ context, like in fashions of veiling, the kotomisi or Rasta-dreads as well as in places of pilgrimage? What items are considered valuable to ‘send back home’ and how is this facilitated? Students will analyse the historical trajectory of a cultural/religious phenomenon specific to a named social group and will, in addition to written sources, reflect on non-written sources, such as oral, visual, material, and/or audio sources.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The 20<sup>th</sup> century coined the “Age of Mobility”, is characterised by ‘mobile’ groups of people without a ‘fixed history’. The aim of the course is to sensitize students to the ways in which ‘mobile’ people continuously negotiate the impact of globalization processes on their cultural/religious identities. By focussing on the materiality of attempts to ‘fix the flow’ students study the emergence of ‘economies of cultural value’. Apart from secondary sources, students will also work with primary sources.</body>

column1: 'Modernity’, the French poet and angry young man Baudelaire once wrote, ‘is the transient, the fleeting, the contingent (….)’, a formulation that has become as famous for its heuristic power as it has become infamous for its interpretative flexibility. In this course we will discuss this elegant, yet slippery statement on the “essence” of modernity by looking into at least two of its many levels of interpretation, i.e. Modernity’s social structures and its structures of experience.

Modernity, conceived as a historical period, is often sharply distinguished from so-called traditional societies by way of the manifold structural changes that occurred in the nineteenth and eighteenth century (and some would even point to the seventeenth century).

We will discuss this radical break or gradual transformation by means of several key witnesses that have been living through (and sometimes even actively shaped) the developments that have come to define modernity. We will pay particular attention to the Enlightenment and the industrialisation process. By reading texts from Enlightenment thinkers such as Immanuel Kant and Georg W. F. Hegel and critical thinkers such as Karl Marx, Hannah Arendt and Michel Foucault you will gain an understanding of the social situation in which they wrote and the historical moment they tried to grasp in words.

While reading and discussing texts from disciplines such as History, Philosophy and the Philosophy of History, we will focus on four interrelated questions that all circle around the notion of ‘Timely Reflections.’ What is the historical context of some of the most canonical thinkers on modernity? What can these thinkers teach us about their historical context? Why did all of these thinkers reflect on History (with a capital ‘H’) and the relation between the past, present and future? And why are their texts still relevant today?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course students are able to

column2: • Describe and explain in which ways Modernity is rooted in the Enlightenment;
• Describe and explain the emergence of typically modern institutions, such as the state, civil society, the family, and the market;
• Describe and explain the industrial revolution and the industrialization of society;
• Describe and explain the ways in which industrialization is related to wider developments such as the emergence of capitalism and urbanization;
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions produce docile bodies by means of disciplinary techniques.
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions are mobilized and have dissolved with the emergence of totalitarian movements and regimes.
• Describe and explain in which ways Enlightenment Reason has been incorporated and criticized in the dominant tradition of modern (continental) philosophy;
• Describe and explain the ways in which canonical thinkers – i.e. Kant, Hegel, Marx, Foucault and Arendt – have reflected on their own times and the concept of History.
• have an understanding of the continuities and discontinuities in the rise of the natural sciences in the 16th to 18th Century;
• have an understanding of the rise of the social sciences and humanities in the 19th Century;
• have knowledge about the ways in which scientists and others (i.e. non-scientists) engage in engage in discussions on ‘objective knowledge’;
• have a understanding of the consequences of the democratization of science
• have a clear understanding of the relations between science, policy and practice.
• can explain how science and technology are as much the products of the societies in which they are embedded as that the give shape to those societies

M de Mul', 'dr. M Heerings', 'dr. M.J. Poleij', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. MD Hilverda', 'dr. MJ Poleij', 'dr. V Petit - Steeghs', 'drs. A Sajjad', 'FE Benning', 'mr. EH Hulst', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Many decisions that you will make as a health care manager or policy maker have an ethical component. Think for instance about decisions concerning national vaccination policies, organizational policies that encourage healthy behavior from staff and government and organizational policies emphasizing the autonomy of patients. Different values are at stake in policies such as these which can conflict with each other. This makes it crucially important for you, as a future healthcare manager or policy maker, to be able to recognize the values at stake and to weigh such values in your decision-making. In the course choices and dilemmas we will provide you with the necessary knowledge and skills to do so.

In this course we use insights from the different disciplines of ESHPM, building on the knowledge you gained in previous courses. In addition we use insights from ethical theory to deepen your knowledge about ethical choices and dilemmas. We also provide you with different tools, such as moral deliberation, for ethical reflection.

In the first part of the course we introduce different ethical values (autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence and justice) and different ethical theories. In the working groups we practice with several methods of ethical reflection. In the second part of the course we go into more detail on specific ethical dilemmas stakeholders experience in practice. In the working groups we reflect on ethical questions you identify in your internship organizations. In the third and final part of the course you write an individual essay on an ethical question or dilemma of your choosing.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>
• Analyze the origin of choices and dilemma’s in healthcare using ethical theory.
• Analyze cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare from different points of view (including different stakeholders, disciplines and ethical theories).
• Use reflective tools such as moral deliberation when analyzing cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare.
• Reflect on his/her own values concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare.
• Write an essay on an ethical dilemma in healthcare using theoretical concepts central in this course.

column1: This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles of 'life', with a focus on molecular and cellular biology. Cell biology studies the structure, function, and behaviour of cells, whereas molecular biology describes the molecular basis of biological activity between various biomolecules (like DNA, RNA and proteins). The course begins with an overview of the main features of bacterial, plant and mammalian cells and goes on to introduce the key molecular players in the cells, i.e. proteins. Techniques that enable characterisation, isolation, and manipulation of cells and biomolecules are central in molecular and cellular biology, and these techniques therefore also play a principal role in this course. Specifically, we will take a close look at microscopy, cell culture, DNA cloning and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technology. We will then move on to study the regulation of gene expression and the eukaryotic cell cycle. We will see how cells are organised in tissues and how intra- and intercellular signalling pathways are involved in controlling cell division, differentiation, and maintenance of the stem cell state. The final part of the course will focus on how DNA can be damaged and repaired, and which molecular events are involved in the generation of cancer.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After taking this course the student will be able to:
• Understand the principles of biological systematics, taxonomy and the classification of ‘life’;
• Identify and describe the structure of bacterial, animal and plant cells (similarities and differences);
• Recognize the vital compartments and organelles of eukaryotic cells and describe their particular function;
• Explain intracellular sorting and transport of molecules (in animal cells) and how this is related to the cytoskeleton and cell movement;
• Recognize excitable animal cells, understanding membrane and action potentials and the cellular interactions within neural pathways;
• Describe the cell cycle: DNA replication, cell growth and division (mitosis and meiosis);
• Explain molecular genetics and epigenetics: the organisation of genomes (emphasis on the human genome); genes and chromosomes; dominant and recessive alleles; inheritance;
• Characterize signal transduction pathways: from an extracellular ligand to transcription activation;
• Understand the regulation of gene expression: the function of promoters, enhancers, transcription factors and small RNAs;
• Describe the various steps involved molecular carcinogenesis;
• Explain the concepts of DNA modification and cloning, including transgenesis;
• Understand the principles of DNA and (whole-) genome sequencing.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89891,2019,Molecular & Cellular Biology Lab,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. AM Aalto'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this practical course, you will become acquainted with microscopy as well as a variety of microbiological and molecular biological techniques. The preparation, planning and execution of the experiments, and the use of specific laboratory materials and equipment, will form a solid introduction to many aspects related to lab work. In microscopy, you will focus on the use and applications of the light microscope. Regarding the microbiological experiments, the focus will be on basic techniques such as the production of culture medium and the plating, staining and quantification of bacteria. The molecular biological techniques that you will perform include the isolation of plasmid DNA and determination of the purity of the DNA by spectrophotometry. In addition, the length of the isolated plasmid DNA will be determined by both restriction enzyme digestion analysis and PCR.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of the course the students will:
• Be able to accurately work with a variable micropipette
• Work according to the general safety rules and the current safe microbial techniques (SMT; in Dutch 'veilige microbiologische technieken' or VMT) rules
• Be able to prepare culture media
• Estimate the quantity of micro-organisms (colony-forming unit)
• Be able to make a DNA UV spectrum and interpret it
• Be able to isolate plasmid DNA from a bacterial culture
• Be able to execute electrophoresis using agarose
• Be able to determine the size of an unknown DNA fragment by means of the electrophoresis data
• Be able to execute a simple PCR experiment and interpret the results
• Be able to operate the light microscope quickly and correctly
• Be able to make various microscopic preparations
• Be able to keep the labjournal in an organised fashion and write lab reports
• Be able to do the calculations involved in these experiments

column2: </body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>This course provides an in-depth coverage of the fascinating field of molecular genetics. We will question how many genes it takes to make a human, how these genes are being regulated at the molecular level, and how genome variation contributes to our individuality. Also, we will discuss the clinical manifestation of the patterns of single-gene inheritance and the complex inheritance of common multifactorial disorders. Using this knowledge, we will see how genetics is being used in a clinical setting for risk assessment, genetic screening and counselling. Furthermore, we will study how (defective) genes can be modified both in humans, animals, and plants through gene editing technologies, with the aim of providing gene therapy, or developing transgenic animals and plants. At the end of this course, you will understand that having an exact count of the necessary number of genes will not be nearly as important as understanding the functions of each gene and how they interact to build the living organism.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you will be able to:

column2: • Understanding the functional differences between genes, pesudogenes and non-coding RNA's
• Ecplain how genes are organized on chromosomes and how they are expressed, i.e. transcribed and translated

• Describe the molecular techniques, such as comparative genomic hybridization (CHG), fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR (qPCR), gene expression profiling (array technology), DNA/RNA sequencing using next generation sequencing technology (NGS), which enabl chromosome and genome analysis that are commonly being used for gene mapping and identification, clinical and prenatal diagnosis and cancer cytogenetics
• Understand the relationship between the genome and proteome, and how proteogenomics can provide valuable additional information on the composition of the genome

• Understand the typical Mendelia pattern of inheritance, or the pattern of transmission of single-gene disorders. You will be able to describe the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which mutations in genes result in recessice, dominant, X-linked and mitochondrial inheritance patterns
• Understand the genetics of common diseases with compex, non-Mendelian, inheritancem and how this relates to disease-predisposing alleles
• Explain the difference between genetic and epigenetic inheritance and the difference between and the molecular mechanisms of X-inactivation and the histone code
• Understand how determination of the recurrence risk is an important aspect of genetic counseling
• Explain the difference and underlying mechanisms of genome, chromosome and gene mutations, and be able to interpret the mutation nomenclature
• Understand how genetic polymorphisms - or single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) determine genetic diversity
• Understand the Hardy-Weinberg law in population genetics and how it's used in genetic counseling
• Understand the principles of linkage and genome-wide association studies (GWAS)
• Explain how susceptibility traits can have high or low risk allele frequency and what the impact of risk allele frequency is on clinical phenotype
• Understand what gene knock-out is and how molecual techniques, such as the Cre-lox and Crispr/Cas systems, enable gene modification in transgenic animals and plants
• Explain how and what type of viruses are being used for enabling gene therapy, and which diseases can be targeted
• Recognize and understand the ethical issues that are connected to prenatal and diagnostic screening, genetically modified organisms (GMO's), and gene therapy

column1: Monetary economics is a very broad topic area that deals with the effects of money, monetary institutions, and monetary policy on macroeconomic variables such as economy output, inflation, interest rates, and exchange rates. In this course we discuss some key theoretical principles behind the monetary policy and the practical issues of its implementation by various central banks.

column2: • What is money and what does it do?
• Interest rate policy of central banks and the effects on financial markets.
• The various transmission channels of monetary policy.
• Testing causality: Do money and monetary policy affect the economy?
• Monetary policy rules and reaction functions.
• Understanding inflation. Why has price stability become the cornerstone of the modern monetary policy?
• Lessons for the monetary policy from the global financial crisis of 2007-2009

column1: This course is an economics course (elective).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand key theoretical principles behind the modern monetary policy.
• Learn practical issues of monetary policy implementation by various central banks.
• Learn the transmission channels of monetary policy monetary policy to macroeconomic outcomes such as output, inflation, and unemployment.
• Read academic and policy papers related to monetary economics
• Work with the economic data and use econometric techniques in order to empirically test the key relationships between monetary and macroeconomic variables.

column1: In this course, students will analyze the tension between fine arts and money, and the problems of commercializing artistic processes. The course will be divided into two parts: in seminars 2 to 4 we will discuss different exchange models for art goods illustrated by historical and contemporary case studies, and in seminars 5 to 8 the focus will be on the specifics of contemporary art markets (prices, values, indices, rules and conventions, and actors).

column2: • gain an understanding of - and be able to explain the different exchange models for art goods;
• picture the main characteristics and actors of the market for fine arts;
• understand, explain and compare the exchange dynamics within contemporary art markets;
• become familiar with tools (datasets and methods) available to assess prices in contemporary art markets.

column1: Note: - The maximum number of participants is 20.

column2: • Due to the subject matter of the course, students are required to have a good knowledge of art history.
<title></title>

column1: The aim of this course is twofold: to gain insight into the economic dimensions of the art world; and to alert students with a variety of interests (like business or society) to the intricate and often problematic interaction between the art world on one hand and the world of money and finance on the other.

Having completed the minor, students will have gained a cultural-economic perspective. They should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective and of the structures and dynamics of art markets.

column1: The 2007/8 mortgage crisis and 2011 Euro crisis demonstrate the importance of well functioning financial markets and organizations. In addition, banks play a crucial role in the allocation of capital and credit in the economy. This course allows you to recognize the common mechanisms behind current and past crises.

First, you will conceptually understand how money and credit are connected and created. These processes help shape a financial system that can INHERENTLY lead to crisis periods. We will then use these concepts to better understand how the 21-st century financial system actually works.

The second half of this course will zoom in on banks, and in particular on the relationship between a bank, a borrower and a depositor. We will discuss the influence of asymmetric information on the functioning of a bank. We will deal with the theory concerning bank runs, deposit insurance, credit rationing and pooling of interest and maturity. We describe how banks came to existence and how they manage the risks involved in supplying credit. The last lecture is destined for discussion of the current financial crisis.
Main topics of this course are:

column2: • Financial systems and the link between money and credit;
• Money, credit, and central banks;
• The creation and sudden evaporation of elasticity in the financial system;
• The reason of existence of banks and their characteristics;
• The relationship between a borrower and a bank (adverse selection, moral hazard, limited liability, credit rationing and risk management);
• The relationship between a depositor or a stockholder and a bank (bank run, deposit insurance and bank regulation).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• At the end of this course, students should understand the mechanisms through which money and credit markets work, and roles and functions of banks.
• Students khow these characteristics have contributed to recent crises, and may contribute to future crises.
• Students will know how to classify financial institutions in terms of a money/credit hierarchy.
• Understand and use models that describe how banks work.

column1: The course considers normative ethics and discusses the four major moral theories that attempt to formulate basic principles of morality: virtue ethics, contractualism, utilitarianism and deontology. It also turns to meta-ethics and moral psychology to discuss more foundational issues such as the nature of morality, of moral motivation and moral agency as well as the structure of moral judgements.

In the first two weeks we will discuss the four major theories, in the second two weeks we will discuss on which assumptions these theories rely and how they can be applied. Which conceptions of the Good are presupposed? How do the theories conceive of the moral agent? And how would each theory deal with concrete moral dilemma cases? </body>

column1: Understand the relation between ethics, meta-ethics, and moral psychology.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87289,2019,Motivatie, zelfregulatie & prestaties",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,[],,"Inhoud

Why do some people perform better than others on work or study related tasks? Why does one person manage to faithfully adhere to an exercise regimen or a healthy diet while others succumb to the temptation of fast-food? Why is it sometimes difficult to put forth the effort to take on a task? Why do you sometimes postpone tasks even though you know you will regret this later? Why are some good intentions doomed to fail from the start? What is the purpose of planning ahead and setting goals? How can people be properly motivated to reach their potential and reach their objectives? These are just some of the central questions within the domain of motivation, self-regulation, and performance that will be addressed in this course. In addition to a short overview of the major theoretical frameworks, you will read empirical research on these topics. Emphasis is put on critical reading of the literature. The theoretical frameworks or topics that will be addressed are emotion regulation, control theory, social cognitive theory, achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, procrastination, and the possible limitation of willpower.
At the end of the course:

column2: • Students are able to differentiate between and compare the different theoretical frameworks on motivation and self-regulation (e.g., achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, ego-depletion).
• Students are able to apply these theories on situations in daily life.
• Students can give examples of self-regulatory mechanisms and are able to describe these mechanisms.
• Students can describe the relationship between motivation, self-regulation, and behavioral outcomes (e.g., performance, learning outcomes, health).
• Students can give examples and explain situations of self-regulatory failure (e.g., procrastination).

column1: Incentives are what drive modern organizations, and employees tend to respond strongly to them. Well-designed incentives encourage employees to use their abilities and knowledge in the firm’s interests. They serve also an important role in recruitment in order to attract the right people to join and stay with the enterprise. Organizations have to address therefore their internal dynamics and external market environment simultaneously in order to create value.

Organizations are not only in markets, but also an alternative to markets. They tend to have characteristics that set them apart from markets, such as employees supplying a subset of their liberties to management, specific human capital, long term relationships, and various possibilities to do more (make better decisions) than any single individual. These features raise issues regarding the determinants of well-functioning organizations, such as ‘Who decides?’ (the allocation of authority, formal versus real authority, access; relational contracts; ratification and monitoring in decision control, and initiation and implementation in decision management; task design; conflict resolution; enforcement mechanisms; talent allocation across hierarchical positions; incompatible languages and communication failures; rigid cultures, …) and ‘Benefits and Costs’ (short-termism, hard versus soft information, vested interests in payment schemes; hiring decisions; …). They will be characterized as motivation problems (employees’ and organization’s interests differ), alignment challenges (lack of coordination across departments), and bounded cognition problems (lack of the necessary information to do so). Successful organizations address them in order to develop and implement policies to create value.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this elective is to make you familiar with the topics at the frontier of the field of Management, especially Organizational Change and Human Resource Management. The aim is to achieve three goals:

column2: • Provide insight in motivation, coordination, and cognition problems in enterprises;
• Improve your multi-person interaction thinking;
• Enable you to develop better enterprise strategies and policies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85755,2019,Multicultureel Ontwikkeling en Onderwijs,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. J Vietze', 'dr. KHR Ouwehand', 'dr. M Meeuwisse']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Tot voor kort was de pedagogische en onderwijskundige wetenschap vooral gericht op wetenschappelijke studies op het gebied van westerse populaties en culturen. Dit heeft voor een westers vooroordeel in kennis en theorie gezorgd. Door mondialisering en migratie ontwikkelingen kan deze kennis over pedagogische en onderwijskundige zaken niet automatisch meer toegepast worden op andere culturen of etnische minderheidsgroepen in Nederland. In de afgelopen jaren is echter veel onderzoek verricht en zijn theorieën ontwikkeld die fenomenen op het gebied van opvoeding en onderwijs in multicultureel perspectief kunnen beschrijven en verklaren. Dit onderzoek en deze theorieën staan centraal in dit blok. Enerzijds worden de basistheorieën behandeld zoals acculturatie theorieën. Anderzijds komen theorieën aan bod die op ontwikkeling en opvoeding betrekking hebben en theorieën die over het onderwijs gaan.

Daarnaast leren de studenten niet alleen over methodologische en theoretische zaken met betrekking tot de wetenschappelijke studie van multiculturele gemeenschappen, maar zij worden ook aangemoedigd om een kritische en beschouwende blik en een ethische en onbevooroordeelde houding te ontwikkelen in de studie naar de ontwikkeling en onderwijs van kinderen vanuit een multicultureel perspectief.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • de migratiegeschiedenis, religie en cultuur van migrantengezinnen te beschrijven (eindtermen 2 en 3);
• een beschrijving te geven van de verschillende acculturatie theorieën (eindterm 1);
• de concepten stereotypen, vooroordelen en discriminatie en de betekenis van de “stereotype threat” te beschrijven. Ook kan de student de contacthypothese beschrijven (eindterm 1);
• een beschrijving te geven van denken over verschillen in relatie tot maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen (eindterm 2).
• verschillende visies op opvoeding en ontwikkeling in verschillende culturen te beschrijven (eindterm 3);

• een beschrijving te geven van multicultureel onderwijs en van intercultureel onderwijs. Daarnaast kan de student enkele toepassingen van verschillende opvattingen over multi- en intercultureel onderwijs beschrijven (eindterm 7);
• een beschrijving te geven van docentverwachtingen en wat docentgedrag is in divers samengestelde klassen en hoe dat verschilt van docentgedrag in homogeen samengestelde klassen (eindterm 3 en 5);
• een omschrijving te geven van burgerschap op school en de manier waarop scholen hier invulling aan geven.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In popular imagination, there seems to be an increasingly common view of ‘East’ and ‘West’ as monolithic entities that differ fundamentally from each other. Historians, philosophers and social scientists have been both involved and concerned with these essentialising labels. The ‘Global South’ is the most recent iteration of a historical, political and economic trend to create geographies based in binary terms.

Adopting the Global History approach within the scientific study of history, a subfield that has engendered great scholarly interest in recent years, we will look at globalisation as an historical process, and at the Global South as a political, economic, and imagined space.

Globalisation and Global History do not refer to the study of the entire world. Rather, they are scientific concepts that describe different processes of political, economic and cultural interaction. We will explore historical dimensions of globalisation as a process that has encompassed the globe. The starting point is recognizing the notion of ‘multiple modernities’: differing experiences departing from the notion of ‘modernity’ as a universalistic Western concept. It thus seeks to highlight voices and perspectives that have traditionally been un(der)-represented in traditional curricula and popular discourse.

Topics covered in the course include economic interdependencies, the use and purpose of colonial violence, decolonisation and transnational solidarities. Finally, we will look at our own historical moment and think through the present-day reverberations of past interactions.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Problematize ‘Europe’ as a cultural construct.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Edward Said’s critique of orientalism.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column1: This course is about museums. The institution will be analysed from an interdisciplinary perspective to discuss the complexity of the context in which institutions operate. The museum is a firm that acts as key player in the heritage market, as intermediary, as judgement devise, as producer of sustainable assets, as generator of jobs, but also as communicator of what society values, an important touristic destination and overall source of joyful cultural consumption. There are museums of every imaginable topic with varied organisational and financing structures, large and small, with a different approach to being digital and exhibition practices. They all affront challenges in the current heritage market.

Every year, a selection of museums will present one current challenges, giving students the opportunity to apply a strong interdisciplinary theoretic framework to the hands-on case.  Students will work in groups to analyse and explain the problem in order to draw recommendations that will culminate in a proposed plan of action for the institution.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89581,2019,Narrative Identities in Literature and Philosophy,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. KME Bauer'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
How do you answer the question Who are you? You can just tell your name. But you can also tell a story.

Philosophical theories of narrative identity presuppose, that narrative structures are essential for the formation and / or self-understanding of personal identity, which is not reducible to a mere numerical identity.

In this course we will discuss different philosophical theories of narrative identity and confront them with different ways of unfolding narrative identities in literature. Literary narratives about fictional or real persons and their life-stories can be fragmented, multi–perspective, and very creative in their handling of fact and fiction. Literature allows us to “try on stories like clothes”. What does this tell us about philosophical theories of narrative identity and their normative implications?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- You will learn to distinguish between different philosophical theories of narrative identity and critically compare them to other theories of personal identity.
– You will be able to critically discuss the normative implications and consequences of different theories of narrative identity as well as of different ways of telling life-stories.
- You will acquire the necessary skills to enter into a fruitful dialogue between philosophy, literary theory and literature.</body>

column1: This course offers a law-and-humanities approach to core topics of law and justice, with a special emphasis on their interrelation.

• Law and the ethics of inclusion and exclusion.

</style>

column1: Geschillen kunnen een puur nationaal karakter hebben maar in toenemende mate zien wij geschillen met een internationale dimensie, waarin vragen van internationaal privaatrecht spelen: welk (materieel) recht is toepasselijk op de zaak, welke rechter is internationaal bevoegd en hoe het zit met de grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van een eventuele uitspraak? Als de procedure zich afspeelt voor de Nederlandse rechter, is het Nederlandse burgerlijk procesrecht van toepassing, maar dat betekent niet dat zich geen ‘grensoverschrijdende’ vragen kunnen voordoen, zoals vragen rondom internationale betekening, bewijs dat uit het buitenland moet worden verkregen en toepasselijkheid van ‘buitenlands’ materieel recht. Ook in ander opzicht doen internationalisering en globalisering zich gelden in het procesrecht. Voor de ontwikkeling van het procesrecht wordt steeds meer gekeken naar de wijze waarop het procesrecht elders is ingericht en in de EU zijn de eerste stappen gezet naar harmonisering van procedures.

Na een introductie in de leerstukken, begrippen en rechtsregels van het internationaal privaatrecht, zullen wij ter aanvulling op en verdieping van het bachelorvak burgerlijk procesrecht een aantal actuele procesrechtelijke thema’s behandelen vanuit nationaal en internationaal perspectief. Zo zullen wij aan de hand van incassozaken de nationale ontwikkelingen rond digitalisering en vereenvoudiging van procedures bestuderen alsook de vragen die spelen in internationale zaken om grensoverschrijdende incasso te vergemakkelijken (harmonisering van procedures, betekening, tenuitvoerlegging etc.). De actuele discussie in Nederland over de verhouding tussen rechter en partijen komt aan de orde, en biedt een aanknopingspunt om ons te verdiepen in het fenomeen forumshopping dat vooral in internationale zaken een rol speelt. In het licht van de rol van de rechter en de partijen besteden we ook aandacht aan de ethische dilemma’s waarvoor rechter en partijen kunnen komen te staan (voorafgaand en tijdens de procedure). Een ander voorbeeld van een thema dat in dit vak aan de orde zal komen is het bewijsrecht. De bewijslastverdeling zal vooral vanuit Nederlands perspectief worden bestudeerd; de bewijsgaring biedt een mooi aanknopingspunt om over de grenzen te kijken. We denken dan enerzijds aan de invloeden uit Europa en andere rechtsstelsels op ons nationale procesrecht (bewijsbeslag, discovery), en anderzijds aan de perikelen van grensoverschrijdende bewijsvergaring. Deze en andere actuele aspecten van het nationaal en internationaal procederen zullen na de tussentoets in de seminars van dit vak centraal staan. In dit vak wordt tevens een brug geslagen naar de praktijk door de organisatie van masterclasses.</body>

• De student kan tijdens een discussie met medestudenten in ethische dilemma’s waarmee de hoofdrolspelers in een procedure kunnen worden geconfronteerd, een beargumenteerd standpunt innemen en verdedigen.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: A necessary condition is a critical determinant of an outcome: if the condition is not in place the outcome will not occur. A student will not be admitted to a PhD program when the GMAT score is too low, creativity will not exist without intelligence, and organizational change will not occur without management commitment. Such single conditions can be a bottleneck for the outcome. If the necessary condition is not in place there is guaranteed failure, and this cannot be compensated by other determinants. But when the condition is in place there is no guaranteed success. The condition is necessary but not sufficient. To prevent failure, each single necessary condition must be in place. Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA) provides the logic and a methodological tool for identifying necessary conditions in datasets.

Necessary conditions are widespread in real life and therefore relevant to various research areas, such as management, business research, sociology, and psychology. But until recently no technique was available to identify necessary conditions in datasets. Traditional (regression based) data analysis techniques fail to do so. Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA) is a rapidly emerging method that can do the job (Dul, 2016; Dul et al., 2020; Dul, 2020).

NCA is applicable to any discipline, and can provide strong results even when other analyses such as regression analysis show no or weak effects. By adding a different logic and data analysis approach, NCA adds both rigor and relevance to theory, data analysis, and publications. NCA is a straightforward and user-friendly method that requires no advanced statistical or methodological knowledge beforehand. It can be used in both quantitative research as well as in qualitative research.

NCA is a rapidly emerging empirical research method that is being used in a variety in fields such as (industrial) psychology, international business, operations management, information sciences, finance, strategy, entrepreneurship, organizational behavior, and human resource management. For example, Van der Valk et al. (2016) identified trust and contracts are necessary for successful collaboration between companies for innovation. Arenius, Engel, and Klyver (2017) tested whether particular gestation activities for establishing a new firm are necessary for profit two years after the firm’s start. De Vries et al. (2017) found that safety consciousness is necessary for driving performance, and Knol et al. (2018) identified several necessary conditions for successful implementation of lean production.  NCA has also been applied outside the social sciences, for example in medicine (Luther et al. 2017).

In general, NCA is particularly useful when several factors contribute to an outcome (multi-causality), and it is not known which factors are essential for that outcome. Research questions may deal with characteristics, efforts and steps of people, teams, and organizations that are crucial for successful outcomes (e.g., high performance).
What are the main advantages of applying NCA:

column2: • It provides new substantive insights in social science phenomena (expressed as necessity rather than average trend); using NCA provides an alternative perspective, may enhance existing research, or falsify theories;
• It has great practical meaning because identified necessary condition must always be put and kept in place;
• Journal editors and reviewers appreciate that authors use a new solid methodology that provides new insights and contributes to academic rigor and practical relevance.
• “From my perspective, it is the most interesting paper I have handled at this journal, insofar as it really represents a new way to think about data analyses""
• “I just added the paper to the required reading list for my doctoral-level seminar on research methods”
• “I believe the paper holds the potential to be widely cited and to change how organizational researchers approach testing for cause and effect relationships”

column1: What participants of this course said about NCA?

column2: • “Simple technique that requires no ‘preparation’, data transformation/manipulation/ correction. A perfect plug-and-play method that can give output in under 10 minutes”
• “It’s a new way of thinking and therefore it may lead to many interesting insights, just reanalyzing old dataset”
• “Analysis provides insights that cannot be obtained with another method”
• “Insights are very relevant for practice”
• “I do believe that is has great exploratory value that is congruent with recent emphasis on big data”

column1: The course is designed for PhD candidates and junior faculty who are aiming for publications in top journals. Other researchers interested in this novel approach—including research master students and senior faculty—are also welcome to take this course. We expect that each participant has at least some experience with traditional regression analysis to understand the differences between NCA and regression, and to appreciate how NCA complements regression. Researchers with a background in Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA) can also benefit from the course to appreciate how NCA complements QCA. No special methodological or substantive knowledge is required for this course. Examples will be drawn from many different (business) fields. Each participant is expected to work on a computer with a Windows (Microsoft) or iOS (Apple) operating system. The exercises with the NCA software (in R) can be done without prior programming knowledge or experience. Zoom will be used for online sessions.
What is the content of the course?
The course consists of the following parts:
Based on the textbook: Dul, J. (2020) Conducting Necessary Condition Analysis. Mastering Business Research Methods series, London: Sage Publications. Sage Publications.

column2: • Discussion 1: Necessity logic in daily life and research [Assignment 1]
• Discussion 2: Necessary condition hypothesis and dataset [Assignment 2]
• Discussion 3: Data analysis with NCA [Assignment 3]
• Discussion 4: Writing up the study [Assignment 4]
• Q&A 1 [Assignment 1]
• Q&A 2 [Assignment 2]
• Q&A 3 [Assignment 3]
• Q&A 4 [Assignment 4]
• Writing a paper [Assignment 5]
• Individual feedback [Assignment 5]

column1: <body>After successful completion of this online course you will be able to:

column2: • Understand the logic of necessary conditions.
• Understand why necessary conditions are important for (social) science.
• Understand why necessary conditions are important for practice.
• Identify and formulate necessary conditions in (your own) theory.
• Identify and test necessary conditions in (your own) data sets.
• Write a paper in which you use necessity logic and apply NCA.

column1: <body>Aan het einde van de 18e eeuw ontwikkelt zich in Duitsland stormachtig het Duits idealisme op basis van de problematiek die Kants kritische filosofie deed ontstaan en die hij  in zijn derde kritiek probeerde te entameren. De basis van dit denken is Kant, met name diens teleologie, dat als model dient voor een geschiedfilosofie, die de geschiedenis leest als een proces van menselijke bevrijding en emancipatie. Hegel meende dat na de Franse Revolutie en Kants kriticisme dit proces zowel in politiek als intellectueel opzicht voltooid is met de opbouw van de moderne (rechts)staat en het ontstaan van een christendom dat tot zijn redelijke kern zou zijn herleid. Rond 1830 begint Hegels roem te verbleken.</body>

column1: Overzicht van de ontwikkeling van de negentiende-eeuwse wijsbegeerte te beginnen bij Kant. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen politieke en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene  en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan jet het interpreteren van filosofische teksten uit de 19e eeuw.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89629,2019,Negentiende eeuw II: Van Kant tot neokantianisme,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh'],,Inhoud

column1: De snelle ontwikkeling en verbreding van de natuurwetenschappen in de achttiende en begin negentiende eeuw krijgen filosofisch een vervolg in de ontwikkeling van een empiristische kenleer en een positivistisch wereldbeeld. Ook vindt tegen deze achtergrond een empirische en ‘wetenschappelijke’ geïnspireerde benadering plaats van maatschappelijke vraagstukken en geven de door de wetenschappelijk bemiddelde visies op kennis, natuur en menselijke samenleving aanleiding tot een steeds pregnanter idee van historische ontwikkeling.

In deze cursus zal het positivische gedachtegoed worden toegelicht aan de hand van denkers als Auguste Comte en Ernst Mach en de verdere ontwikkeling van de positivistische methodiek worden uitgelegd aan de hand van het empirisme van John Stuart Mill. Ook zullen sociale ideeën van zowel Comte als Mill worden behandeld. Zowel de historiserende als de methodologische en kentheoretische aspecten van het negentiende eeuwse denken komen terug in de behandeling van het werk van Charles Darwin en de reflectie op de filosofische gevolgen daarvan. Vanuit de Duitstalige traditie zal met name aandacht worden besteed aan Arthur Schopenhauer en Friedrich Nietzsche, die beiden een unieke positie veroverden in het filosofische landschap van de Negentiende Eeuw.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus zijn studenten in staat de belangrijkste thema’s uit de geschiedenis van de wijsbegeerte van de negentiende eeuw toe te lichten aan de hand van filosofische ontwikkelingen in Frankrijk, Engeland en Duitsland volgend op de periode van het Hegelianisme. De studenten krijgen een elementair inzicht in de wijze waarop de filosofische posities zich tot elkaar verhielden en hoe de historische ontwikkeling van filosofische vraagstellingen gedurende het tijdvak verliep. Waar dat van nut is voor een beter begrip van de thema’s worden filosofische ideeën in de bredere context geplaatst van culturele, politieke en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen.
