column1: De klassieke Oudheid vormt het begin van de Westerse wijsbegeerte; met name de Griekse Oudheid kenmerkt zich door een verbazingwekkende rijkheid aan filosofen en denkbeelden, die ons denken tot op de dag van vandaag op diepgaande wijze hebben beïnvloed. De cursus begint met de eerste Griekse filosofen, nog voor Socrates, en vervolgens zullen diens leven en ideeën worden behandeld binnen de contekst van het Athene van de vijfde eeuw voor Christus. Vervolgens komt de metafysische en de kentheoretische invulling aan bod die Plato gaf aan de erfenis van Socrates, waarna de filosofie van diens leerling Aristoteles wordt behandeld. Daarbij zal aandacht worden besteed aan diens metafysica, kenleer, logica, ethiek en (mogelijk ook) zijn politieke filosofie. De periode vanaf Aristoteles kenmerkt zich door de dramatische historische veranderingen die in gang worden gezet door zijn beroemdste leerling, namelijk Alexander de Grote. Door diens veroveringen breidt de Griekse wereld zich uit over het gehele oostelijke gedeelte van de Middellandse Zee en ver daarbuiten. In de Hellenistische periode daarna ontwikkelen zich de Stoïsche en Epicureïsche scholen, die zich concentreren op logica, een materialistische fysica en vooral een ethiek waarin de afwezigheid van leed als het hoogste goed wordt verdedigd. De cursus wordt afgesloten met het syncretische gedachtengoed van de neoplatonist Plotinus.
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

Zie het Studiereglement, Onderwijs- en Examenreglement, artikel 4.3 lid 3: ‘Binnen de Nederlandse cursussen in het eerste en tweede jaar van de bachelor worden werkcolleges aangeboden die verplicht zijn voor de voltijdse studenten. Studenten mogen voor één werkcollege per cursus met toestemming van de docent afwezig zijn, voor een volgende afwezigheid is toestemming van de Examencommissie vereist. Afwezigheid zonder instemming van de Examencommissie heeft tot gevolg dat de student een door de docent te bepalen extra opdracht dient te maken waarvan het resultaat meetelt voor het eindresultaat van de cursus.’ Voor de cursus Oudheid betekent deze regeling voor de voltijders: meer dan één keer afwezig bij een werkcollege zonder toestemming van de Examencommissie = 1 schriftelijke opdracht extra inleveren per verzuimd werkcollege, bovenop de twee opdrachten die sowieso verplicht zijn; als op die manier meer dan in totaal twee opdrachten worden ingeleverd, dan tellen de twee laagst becijferde opdrachten mee voor het eindcijfer.

In bepaalde gevallen kunnen zij ook filosofische ideeën relateren aan culturele, politieke en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen.</body>

In het vak Overheid en Informatiesamenleving staan de elektronische overheid, digitale democratie en de informatiesamenleving centraal. Voor elk van de thema's geldt dat niet zozeer de techniek wordt benadrukt. Er wordt wel nadrukkelijk aandacht gevraagd voor de besluitvorming over (de wijze van) toepassing van de technologie in of rondom het openbaar bestuur, de gevolgen voor organisatie, beleid en samenwerkingsrelaties, en de wijze waarop verschillende 'stakeholders' in en rondom organisaties omgaan met informatie en kennis die wordt verzameld, verwerkt en verspreid met behulp van ICT. Dit laatste thema is met name voor een sociaal-wetenschappelijke benadering van groot belang; informatie en kennis worden in de literatuur wel gepresenteerd als neutrale grootheden, maar in de (beleids)praktijk geldt dat vaak uiteenlopende interpretaties van informatie (denk bijvoorbeeld aan de verschillende wijzen waarop klachten van burgers kunnen worden geïnterpreteerd) ontstaan bij verschillende stakeholders, en dit geeft vervolgens vaak aanleiding tot onverwachte en complexe interactiepatronen in en tussen organisaties.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Pain is an all-too-familiar problem and the most common reason that people see a physician. Pain is an adaptive process and serves an important purpose by alerting us to potential tissue damage and injuries and thereby inducing protective reactions. For a long time, pain was considered as a purely physical sensation and symptom of an underlying somatic disease. In the last decades, it has become clearer and clearer that pain is a psycho-biological experience including sensory and emotional components.

In this course, students will be introduced to the biological and psychological underpinnings of pain and experimental paradigms to investigate pain in the psychological laboratory. The main focus will be on psychological factors of pain such as the influence of emotions, attention, expectations (placebo-effect). Other topics of this course include phenomena such as phantom limb pain or chronification of pain and their underlying neurocognitive mechanisms. Furthermore, diagnostics of pain and different psychological treatment approaches will be discussed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to increase students' knowledge of a topic, which has gained increased interest in Clinical Psychology in recent years: Pain and its modulation by psychological factors. The main goal is for students to learn about recent scientific insights into the neurobiological basis and psychological models of pain, its modulation by psychological factors, and (psychological) treatment methods.

column1: <body>Panel data analysis is concerned with data that run over time for different units of observations. That can be individuals, households, firms, regions, countries, etc. The repeated nature of the data enables the use of more realistic econometric models (for example, incorporating dynamics at the individual level), more robust estimation methods (e.g. controlling for unobserved heterogeneity) and more powerful testing procedures (e.g. testing for long-run purchasing power parity by pooling a number of countries). On the other hand, the panel nature of the data introduces some complications, including possible parameter heterogeneity, serial correlation or error component structures of the error terms, and cross-sectional dependence. These issues are particularly disturbing in nonlinear or dynamic models. The course will provide an insightful and useful elaboration of the state of the art in empirical panel data analysis at an introductory level. Starting from a general introduction, discussing advantages and disadvantages of panel data, static models with fixed effects or random effects, instrumental variables estimators, clustered standard errors and robust inference, the course focuses on (micro-economic) dynamic models, where the time dimension is typically limited and the number of cross-sectional units is large. Topics covered include fixed effects and random effects models, instrumental variables, estimation by the Generalized Method of Moments (GMM), and models with limited dependent variables. </body>

column1: <body>The course gives the participants the opportunity to have theory sessions in the morning combined with practical cases in the computer hall with Stata in the afternoon. Participants will work in small teams and Professor Verbeek will assist and give feedback. It’s been assumed that participants are familiar with basic econometric methods and models, including linear regression, serial correlation, simply hypothesis testing, heteroskedasticity, endogeneity and instrumental variables, and simple dynamic modeling. The course will avoid matrix notations as much as possible. The course will be supported by class slides, empirical exercises and reading material (book chapters and journal articles).</body>

column1: This MA seminar takes the ubiquity of digital media technologies as a starting point and aims to understand and explain how traditional roles of (media) audiences have changed and how these developments impact the way producers and organizations try to reach their audiences. Although the Web2.0 enthusiasts are overtly positive about active user roles and applaud the online possibilities of user participation, others approach the activities of users with caution and skepticism. Some critics claim that self-publishing undermines our sense of what is true and what is false and corrupts our culture. Another issue that keeps surfacing in the debate on the changes brought by the internet and digitization is about the control over and ownership of content. Also, some researchers question if users are truly active and empowered online. They point, for example, to the fact that only a small percentage of the audience is participating in the creation of online content.

The central topic of this seminar is the reconfiguration of the traditional consumer/producer relationship in the online media domain. We will specifically focus on the role of algorithms, platforms and on topics related to societal and cultural issues, for example, the possibilities and limitations of self-expression online as well as the options for civic engagement through new media. Theoretically, the approach is informed by the Social Shaping of Technology perspective, Uses and Gratifications theorizing and theories on civic engagement. In class, we will study and critically assess different theoretical perspectives on participating users and analyze various assumptions that are often made about active or inactive users and the possible consequences for culture and society.

In the second part of the seminar, students will conduct an ‘Internet safari’ to spot interesting and possibly exotic cases of contemporary online audience participation. These cases will be analyzed by using the theories taught in the seminar. The analysis will be reported in a final, summative paper.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The value of different theoretical perspectives on (participating) online media users.
• The value of empirical research on new media users.
• The ways in which scientific knowledge can be applied to a relevant case study.
• Analyze recent and future trends in new media usage.
• Reflect critically on the claims made by researchers and theorists from different perspectives.
• Take and defend different theoretical positions.
• Independently analyze an empirical case study.

column1: In our network society, many organizations face challenges to find, keep or satisfy their customers. Internet tools and social media enable people to be connected with each other 24 hours a day and to participate in the creation, distribution, marketing and evaluation of products and services. It is of vital importance for organizations to understand networks and participation, to boost  engagement and to use, for example, the collective intelligence of their customers to strengthen their position or improve their service or product. The aim of this course is to make you think about strategic ways for organizations to integrate customer participation on various levels to improve the way they function in society. In this course, we will take conceptualizations and the theoretical approaches focusing on participation as a starting point to design a solution for a practical challenge. In the process, you will learn how to advise organizations on how they can incorporate customer participation in their business model.

The topics we deal with in this course are (amongst others): User engagement, collective intelligence, social media, immaterial labor, user-generated content, motivations for participation on various levels (U&G), storytelling and participation inequality. The result of this seminar is a video presentation in which you will present your advice to an organization.</body>

This third course in the Politics & Society specialisation focuses on the political relevance of different types of globalisation for political parties, governments, and domestic and international policy. First, we focus on the new challenges that political parties face due to globalisation. It inspires their reconsideration of actions, strategies, and guiding principles, poses threats to some of these, while it provides opportunities for other ones. Hotly debated topics that will be addressed in this course are questions such as whether globalisation explains the rise of new populist parties, whether it leads to fragmentation of the party landscape, and whether it affects party ideologies. Second, contemporary governments have to deal with all abovementioned aspects and political corollaries of globalisation. The general question is how governments behave in a globalised context. Governments and their constituting political parties increasingly have to navigate between the often conflicting demands of their constituency and international obligations, such as those stipulated by the European Union (EU). Do they, for instance, pursue a politics of austerity as agreed upon in response to the European financial and debt crises, and consequently reform the welfare state? And how do governments respond to other globalisation-related issues, such as immigration and asylum applications? Do governments become less generous? And what role do party ideology, party competition, public opinion, NGO’s, and business interests play in the process?

Third, we discuss the increased impact of supranational organizations like the EU, transnational networks and civil society organizations on citizens and policies. How do international organizations like the EU try to resolve social problems such as unmanaged mass migration, terrorism and climate change? How do citizens perceive the EU and what factors explain the differential support for EU integration across individuals and countries? Moreover, does public opinion and the changing party landscape affect the EU and its institutions as well?

Note: This course builds on theories, concepts, and research findings discussed in the first two courses in Politics & Society (that is, The Social Bases of Politics and Political Attitudes and Behaviour in Context). We allow up to five elective students. Students who have at least attended one and preferably both of the two prior courses in Politics & Society are eligible to apply. Selection will be based on both prior knowledge and motivation. Note that basic knowledge of quantitative social-scientific methods is needed in order to understand a substantial part of the mandatory literature.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Differentiate among the types and aspects of globalisation processes taking place;
• Explain social-scientific theories on how globalisation influences party systems, party ideologies, and government behaviour;
• Explain social-scientific theories on the way in which governments and policies related to global issues are influenced by tensions between domestic politics and international obligations;
• Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics to contemporary politicalhenomena;
• Discuss the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics;

• Formulate and test a theoretically informed hypothesis related to the impact of globalization on political institutions and/or government policies by conducting a basic quantitative analysis of secondary data;
• Orally present the findings of the above-mentioned analysis to an informed audience.

column1: “But why can’t I patent in Europe just because I talked about the invention at a conference?” “But I thought the claims in my patent would stop my competitor marketing that product!” “I invented an improvement! So why do I have to get a licence from them before I can market my own invention?” “So I would have been better off just keeping this process secret rather than patenting it?”

Intellectual property is a vital asset for firms today, and patent portfolios can be extremely valuable. Yet all too often managers know little about patent law and patent strategies. This ignorance can be costly, because a naïve manager is like a lamb going to the slaughter-house. Skilful competitors will slice and dice a poorly worded patent that is in their way, or use a variety of other patent strategies to hinder the goals of their less knowledgeable and less experienced counterparts.

This elective combines theory and practice. The course starts with an overview of all forms of IP, as managers need to be able to identify all the different sorts of IP that can attach to one product. It then briefly examines the basics of patent law; what is not patentable and the problems associated with patenting AI and software; the patent application with particular attention to patent claims and what constitutes patent infringement. We will look at how patents have increasingly become a strategic weapon rather than just a means of protecting an invention from imitation. With Sun Tzu’s ‘Art of war’ as a guide, we will look at the different strategies businesses use.  Patenting is not, however, always the best option. Alternatives to patenting will also be examined.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: “Companies’ biggest assets today are intangible ones like patents. And that’s true not just in technology intensive industries…IP savvy business leaders believe that, in a world where battles are increasingly being waged not for control of markets or raw materials but for the rights to new ideas and innovations, the management of intellectual property must become a core competence of the successful enterprise.” (Rivette and Kline in Harvard Business Review).

They are right. It is time that understanding intellectual property (IP), and in particular patents as the most expensive form of IP, became a ‘core competence’ of any graduate from a business school. Patents have become a strategic business tool and every manager has to know how to use that tool and how it will be used against you. So if you think understanding about patent law and strategy is only a matter for inventors, technicians and lawyers, you are very badly mistaken. Today it is more often the managers of a firm, rather than the R&D department that makes decisions about IP. Every manager in every firm needs to be aware of how IP impacts upon business.

The aim of this elective is to make sure students are prepared for management in a business environment that is increasingly dominated by IP. It will provide students with insight into some of the legal and practical issues that arise when firms use the inventions of others or wish to protect their own inventions. After this course, students will understand the basics of patent law and patent claims, how patents are used as a strategic tool of competition, and when patenting is not the best alternative.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms of heart diseases. The students will be able to integrate the information acquired in other disciplines such as Life Support, Human Anatomy, and Human Physiology. The general approach to study the different diseases will include four essential components: cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations). During this course, students will also learn skills that will help them to structure the acquired knowledge in a clinical context.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases affecting the heart. At the end of this course, you will:

column2: • have obtained fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of cardiology.
• describe, distinguish and analyze how specific diseases affect the function of the heart, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
• explain why particular symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
• know how to apply diagnostic tools and clinical skills;
• distinguish and evaluate the different available therapeutic approaches for the various diseases.

Student will expand their knowledge of the physiology of the GI tract, pancreas and liver in health, and they will be able to describe the pathophysiological mechanisms leading to disease. column1: In this course, the students will integrate the knowledge obtained in the previous Pathology and Pathogenesis courses. They will learn about the role of the endocrine system in maintaining homeostasis, and they will be able to describe how the secretion of hormones is regulated, and how disruption of the normal physiology can lead to different diseases. Finally, the students will develop the ability to evaluate, treat and monitor common endocrine disorders, and also familiarise themselves with less common endocrinological afflictions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89336,2019,Patient Centered Care Delivery,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. L Vestjens - van der Mee', 'dr. RA Scheepers', 'dr. SJ Kuipers', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. JM Cramm', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the course 'Patient Centred Care Delivery' (PCCD) students will be taught the most important theories, recent systematic reviews and empirical findings regarding PCCD. During the last decade more and more attention has been given to PCCD; organisations aim to deliver care that is patient centred in order to improve patient outcomes. Evidence indeed has shown that PCCD results in improved health, health behaviour, and quality of life of patients as well as their family/caregivers. Still, evidence is inconclusive and organisations and professionals are generally unknowledgeable and struggle on how to improve PCCD and support interaction between professionals and patients in such a way that it stimulates co-care delivery between them (week 1).
During the second week attention will be given to various forms of interactions between professionals and patients and legal aspects of informed consent and shared decision making

(week 2). Behind every professional there is a team that influences quality of care delivery to patients. Nowadays with an astonishing rise of chronically ill patients and multi-morbidity patients professionals are dealing with patients with complex and multiple needs. These changing needs from acute to chronically ill patients ask for a different approach from organisations regarding their care delivery. Interprofessional collaboration is needed to support the needs of these patients, which requires communication and coordination between professionals from various occupational backgrounds and a supportive team climate (week 3). In turn, effectiveness of these teams is influenced by the culture, structure and availability of resources within the larger organisation. Also leadership affects interprofessional collaboration between professionals and in turn quality of care delivery to patients (week 4). In order to create co-care delivery between professionals and patients diversity in care delivery is needed. Just as professionals operate within a team and organisational context patients are influenced by their environment as well. Patients differ in their educational level for example, their ability to self-manage their well-being and in coping with their disease or illnesses. Special attention will be given to the continuing rise of socioeconomic health inequalities and how culture influences effectiveness of care delivery (week 5). Patients are not only influenced by their individual/personal environment, but by their neighbourhood context as well, especially in regard to improve healthy lifestyles and active and healthy ageing. In the final week we will discuss the role of neighbourhoods and innovative solutions in the community (community health nurses, collaboration between health, social care and informal networks on PCCD and patient outcomes (week 6).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can list the important theories and conceptual models concerning PCCD.
• Students can use theories, concepts, instruments and models from the scientific literature to explain how organisation of care delivery and interprofessional collaboration contributes to PCCD.
• Students will have a proper understanding of Shared Decision Making (SDM). They can also argue its pros and cons compared to other medical decision-making models.

• Students can explain the shift from acute to chronic care and how this leads to changing demands of patients, changing roles and expectation of patients (e.g. having a more active role, self-care and self-management) and that this requires different interaction between professionals and patients, and a different approach in the organization of care delivery to improve PCCD.

• From theories and empirical evidence students can explain how socioeconomic status and culture influences effectiveness of care delivery and convincingly defend that diversity in care delivery is needed to improve patient outcomes and enhance PCCD.

• From theoretical frameworks, conceptual models and innovative solutions students can clearly explain the role of neighbourhoods in health, health behaviour and quality of life of communitydwelling people, especially concerning age-friendly communities to stimulate healthy and active ageing among community-dwelling older people.

column1: <body>For most students, the start of their first year of university is an interesting, but hectic period. Not only will you face new exciting experiences, you may also encounter more demanding responsibilities than before. You are faced with the challenge of choosing a career path and how to develop yourself professionally, as well as the challenge of balancing your new responsibilities with different aspects of your life. To promote the attitudes and skills that help you to become more resilient to life’s demands and to develop yourself in various domains, EUC offers its students the Personal Development Track (PDT). The aim of this track is precisely to help you through the process of self-development.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to acquire basic knowledge of the most recent scientific views concerning the origins of the universe, chemistry, biology (life), and humans. This course addresses fundamental theories concerning evolution from an interdisciplinary perspective.
At the end of the course, you will:

column2: <li>have acquired fundamental knowledge about the major origins in big history, i.e.:
<ul>

column3: • the origin of the stars and chemistry;

column2: • understand how the major origins are connected;
• understand the various interdisciplinary perspectives on big history;
• have acquired a comprehensive overview of the history of the universe, solar system, Earth, life, and modern humans;
• be able to use the skills needed in the EUC's problem-based learning (PBL) environment.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course consists of 4 different parts.  However, due to the nature of the content, these 4 parts do not correlate perfectly with the 4 lectures and the assignments.
Part 1: Interview strategy, your story, your aspirations

During the 1st lecture, we will fast forward all the way to the end and describe both what an interview strategy looks like and explore one of its key components: how to tell your story.  In the associated homework assignment, you will reflect on your motivations, strengths and personality traits to try & articulate a possible career direction - all of which should be the basis for the other part of the assignment: a first draft of your story.
Part 2: Tell me about a time when...

In the 2nd lecture, we will explore how to recount in story-like manner your meaningful personal and professional experiences.  In the associated 2nd and 3rd assignments you will develop a portfolio of powerful stories that you can recount as you navigate through your job search and the recruitment process.

In the 3rd lecture, we will explore various high impact tools to help you build your network by connect with unknown people eager to help.  You will learn how to reach out and how to conduct impactful conversations with them so that you can get advice from them and learn about the market and opportunities.  In the associated assignment you will conduct a conversation with one such person and report back on your findings and experience.

In final, lecture, we will complete our exploration of interview strategies.  In particular, you will learn about the non-story aspects of job interviews. In the associated assignment you will develop an interview strategy for a potential interview with one of your target employers.

Although course attendance is not compulsory, it is strongly recommended for ALL lectures.  Satisfactory completion of the Assignments will require a detailed understanding of concepts that will be discussed during class and that the materials alone cannot cover.  Out of respect for your fellow classmates and faculty, plan to attend sessions in full from beginning to end: joining late and leaving early are not acceptable options.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

What would you say if you could approach the job search process with clarity of purpose, confidence and knowing both how to secure interviews and thrive in them?  The overall objective of this course is to provide you cutting-edge tools and methodologies to:

column2: • Find out what makes you uniquely attractive as a job candidate
• Decide what you want to do
• Build a network of people eager to help you
• Learn about the less visible job opportunities
• Secure job interviews
• Pass interviews

column1: By the end of this course you will be able to:

column2: • Identify your career-relevant strengths, traits, values and motivations
• Build and engage professional networks to obtain advice and identify career opportunities
• Use the art of storytelling to talk about yourself, your past experiences and your professional aspirations in multiple recruiting contexts such as networking and job interviews
• Develop job interview strategies and execute them

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In dit blok staan persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en identiteitsstoornissen centraal. Er zal eerst gekeken worden naar het onderscheid tussen normale persoonlijkheidstrekken en persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Persoonlijkheidsstoornissen vormen een aparte as binnen de DSM-V en kunnen worden onderverdeeld in drie clusters. Cluster A bestaat uit de paranoïde, schizoïde en schizotypische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Cluster B omvat de antisociale, de borderline, de theatrale en narcistische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Tot cluster C worden de ontwijkende of vermijdende, de afhankelijke, de obsessief-compulsieve of dwangmatige persoonlijkheidsstoornis gerekend. In dit blok zal dieper worden ingegaan op het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek en de behandeling van bovengenoemde stoornissen. Daarnaast zal in dit blok ook aandacht worden besteed aan de rol die identiteit speelt bij persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Tevens zullen de dissociatieve stoornissen en genderidentiteitsstoornissen aan bod komen. Tot slot zal er middels een opdracht ook aandacht worden besteed aan impulscontrole stoornissen. Ook hierbij staan wederom het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek, de behandeling en actuele theoretische inzichten centraal.

In dit blok wordt door middel van twee opdrachten dieper ingegaan op relevante onderwerpen. Ten eerste zal middels een blokopdracht aandacht worden besteed aan stoornissen binnen de impulscontrole. Tevens zal er middels een blokopdracht aandacht besteed worden aan zelfreflectie door middel van het invullen en interpreteren van de Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ).</body>

column1: <body>Today, personality psychology and research into the differences between individuals forms an important fundamental basis for the daily practice of psychologists. Psychologists select people for jobs in corporate life based on personality research. If psychologists treat psychological disorders, they often collect information on a patient’s personality. Personality psychology research is therefore an important basis for every student who wants to work in such diverse fields as clinical research, forensic psychology, or human resource management etc. The course Personality Psychology examines the patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviour that make a person unique but at the same time similar to others. In doing so, the course provides students with a broad introduction into the major themes that govern Personality Psychology.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • You can define and understand the overarching concepts of personality and individual differences;
• You have an understanding of and are able to distinguish between the different perspectives on personality;
• You can explain how key aspects of personality and individual differences contribute to understanding human behaviour;
<li>You can apply scientific knowledge of a personality perspective such that you can analyse and solve a small real-world problem that is grounded in individual differences. This means:
<ul>

column3: • You will have the basic skills to analyse and clarify a problem brought up by a client;
• You are able to write a proposal for a client;
• You can justify your choice of literature/theories and methodology;
• You are able to apply literature/theories into practice to solve a small real-world problem;
• You are able to write an advisory report for a client.

column1: Hoewel mensen in zeer veel opzichten van elkaar kunnen verschillen, zal dit blok met name gaan over verschillen in de persoonlijkheid van mensen. Het blok besteedt aandacht aan de belangrijkste invalshoeken, waaronder de psychoanalytische theorie, de leertheorie, humanistische theorieën en trekkentheorieën. Ook zal het blok stilstaan bij theorieën over intelligentie en over de rol van genetische en omgevingsfactoren die gedrag kunnen verklaren. Daarnaast zal het blok een inleiding geven in een aantal psychometrische basisbegrippen en het meten van individuele verschillen.

column1: <body>Doel van dit blok is bekend te raken met de psychologische theorieën over persoonlijkheid en gedrag. Hoe zijn mensen geworden wie zij zijn? Wat is de rol van de opvoeding? Hoe stabiel en voorspelbaar is gedrag eigenlijk? Welke benaderingen zijn er om persoonlijkheid te meten? In dit blok zal de student proberen op deze en andere vragen een antwoord te vinden.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85652,2019,Personnel selection,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. MPh Born'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: In dit blok richten we ons op de thematiek van personeelswerving, -selectie, classificatie en plaatsing. Theorieën en technieken komen aan bod voor het effectief passen van individuele behoeften, voorkeuren, kennis, capaciteiten en vaardigheden, met de behoeften en voorkeuren van de organisatie. We besteden onder meer aandacht aan voorspellings- en besluitvormingsmodellen tijdens selectie. Voorts gaan we in op utiliteitsmodellen, anti-discriminatiemodellen, klinische en statistische predictie, en validiteitsgeneralisatie. Onderwijsgroepsbijeenkomsten hebben de vorm van het maken van opdrachten die gerelateerd zijn aan bovenstaande thema’s nadat deze zijn behandeld tijdens college. Het bijwonen van de colleges is van cruciaal belang voor de onderwijsgroepen.

column2: </body>

column3: Dit blok heeft tot doel de student een grondig inzicht te verschaffen in de theorie en praktijk van personeelselectie. Enerzijds is er een duidelijk accent op statistische modellen voor voorspelling en besluitvorming bij selectie en theorievorming over selectie. Anderzijds wordt er middels een practicum stilgestaan bij best practices op dit vlak door een goede worteling in de praktijk van selectie en socialisatie.</body>

column1: Als professional in de zorgsector zet je je in voor anderen. Om dit op een betrokken en bewuste wijze te doen, is het van belang dat een student zichzelf goed kent. Met meer inzicht over jezelf en je eigen handelen, maak je ook professionele en persoonlijke keuzes die beter bij je passen. De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn helpt een student te ontdekken hoe hij/zij zijn/haar (zelf)kennis het beste in de echte wereld kan toepassen en hoe de student, als uniek persoon, een verschil kan maken in de zorg. De lijn is gecentreerd rondom zeven kernthema’s: leren studeren, zelfsturing, reflecteren, projectmatig werken, samenwerken, presenteren en feedback geven en ontvangen.

Onder begeleiding worden met behulp van bijeenkomsten en thuisopdrachten verschillende thema’s  behandeld. Middels het uploaden van opdrachten in verschillende vormen (voiceclip, filmpje, reflectie-opdrachten, etc.), bouwt de student per jaar een eigen ePortfolio op die in het teken staat van zijn/haar ontwikkeling.

column1: De student kan aan het eind van de Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn:

column2: • een (studie)planning opstellen, studievaardigheidstechnieken toepassen en prioriteiten stellen
• in een team met elkaar een doel realiseren binnen de beschikbare tijd en met het gewenste eindresultaat,
• zijn persoonlijkheid duiden inclusief zijn sterke en zwakke punten en hoe dit samenwerking in groepen beïnvloedt,
• de regels van feedback geven (4G’s) en ontvangen (3B’s) toepassen,
• een effectieve en visueel aantrekkelijke presentatie geven in het Engels en Nederlands,
• reflecteren op zijn eigen gedragingen en leerproces m.b.v. het STARR-model,
• persoonlijke leerdoelen opstellen en terugkijkend op het jaar, reflecteren op het eigen leerproces en SMART doelen stellen voor de studie en professionele toekomst.

column2: <title></title>

column1: A pharmaceutical pricing strategy is more than simply setting a price to recover R&D investments and adding a mark-up to guarantee a desired profit level. Indeed, a price has often little to no relationship to manufacturing costs in this market. It is the perceived value of a new drug in a broad sense, and how a drug is positioned in the market, that is critical to its success. Especially now that development costs are growing, blockbusters are being displaced by niche drugs, treatment is increasingly personalized, and governments are limiting expenditure on healthcare. For a pharmaceutical company, getting sufficient returns on investments and keeping the pipeline filled becomes increasingly challenging.

Many pharmaceutical companies have shifted their focus from sales and marketing to strategic pricing and market access. This has been accompanied by a shift from a product-centered culture to a disease service-centered culture. Clinicians remain important decision makers, but they must move within the boundaries set by payers. Payers are now the ultimate and most influential clients of the pharmaceutical industry.

The course Pharmaceutical Pricing and Market Access (PPMA) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of this complex and changing market. We will follow each step of the life cycle of a drug, from phase II clinical trials up to post-launch, integrating both market access theory and examples from the real world. We will discuss the importance of optimizing product launches, real world post marketing studies and innovative pricing agreements. Students will gain insight into how the latest changes in regulations, guidelines and stakeholders in the major EU, US and BRIC countries impact the success of brands, as well as the interactions between all the actors on the markets. They will learn to understand how differences between healthcare systems impact optimizing market access for pharmaceutical products.

column2: • 12 interactive lectures with plenary discussion (2 lectures of 3 hours each per week)

• 6 small workgroup meetings (2 hours, once per week) with 10 to 15 students using Problem Based Learning to formulate learning goals, exchange knowledge and have discussions about the case of the week. Problem Based Learning is an active way of learning that gives you better retention of knowledge, enhances your motivation and encourages you to develop skills that are essential for the labour market in the 21st century.
• 2 meetings in which small groups of (around 3 to 4) students present a business case and debate about the presented market access strategies

column1: The written examination is 70% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the two presentations on the business cases (10% of the final grade for each case) and participation during the workgroup sessions (10%). Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

The presentations of the business cases are scheduled in the third and sixth week and the students’ presence is obligated. The minimum grade for the weighted average of the written examination and the business cases is 5.5. There will be 1 re-sit of the written examination and no re-sits of the presentations. No reading materials and notes are allowed during the exam, other than an English dictionary. A calculator is allowed.
The re-sit is composed as one single written examination that comprises the entire course learning goals and thus counts for 100%.

column1: <body>By the end of the course students will:

column2: • Have insight in pharmaceutical cost and pricing trends and the drivers thereof;
• Be able to reason how the life cycle of a drug is affected by different aspects of life cycle management;
• Know how pricing and reimbursement systems of key international markets work;
• Understand key concepts of pharmaceutical innovation, pricing and market access (e.g. value based pricing, price referencing, market access arrangements);
• Be able to develop a pricing and market access strategy for drugs;
• Understand how the market for medical devices differs from the drug-market.
• Be trained in Problem Based Learning, public speaking and debating the topics mentioned above

column1: The goal of the course is to make students acquainted to elementary concepts and ideas in philosophy that are relevant for economics. In particular, issues in the methodology of economics, such as how unrealistic models can (and should) be and how we can appraise their explanatory power, and issues in ethics of economics, such as inequality, distributive justice and the moral limits of markets, are discussed. In five tutorials, ethical issues in business and in the market are discussed and analyzed. By active engagement with these topics, students develop a stronger moral sense and they familiarize themselves with theoretical frameworks that enable them to form their own considerate opinion.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89541,2019,Philosophy and Public Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CB Binder'],,Leerdoelen

column2: <title></title>

column1: How can philosophers contribute to public policy? We will explore this question from theory and practice. In a first step we will discuss the role of philosophers in society and different ways of how philosophers can and should or should not contribute to public policy. In a second step, you will learn to apply your skills as a philosopher to public debates and public policy, with the guidance of policy advisor and philosopher Manuel Buitenhuis. After finishing this course, you will have (i) gained insights in applying philosophical skills to topics in public policy, (ii) acquired a deeper understanding of philosophical issues underlying a number of important policy areas, and (iii) have acquired important philosophical skills that are relevant for a position in policy, such as  to conduct policy-oriented research and develop research-based policy reports.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: The lectures and seminar-discussions will focus on the following issues:
1.         The sources of human rights law within the system of public international law.
2.         Human rights as a specific modern discourse: the complementarity of constituting state power and controlling state-power.
3.         Human rights between democracy and the Rule of Law.
5.         Facing the limits of autonomy as sovereignty.
7.         Legal, political and ethical skepticism about human rights.
8.         Current human rights questions surrounding globalisation and populism.

The teaching method will be inductive and bottom-up: ‘learning by experience’. It means that students will engage in philosophical reflection on human rights issues while studying relevant literature and by presenting and exchanging their findings in the seminar.

The discussions will be introduced, prepared and reviewed by the lecturers (master class method). By doing so, the lecturers will offer the participants a philosophical method aimed at bringing to the surface implicit normative assumptions within a human rights discourse. They will also offer them the means to question these assumptions.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The overall aim of this course is to encourage and teach students to reflect critically on human rights and human rights issues, from a theoretical/philosophical perspective. More specifically, after completing the course students should be able to:

column2: • understand the history of ideas of human rights and of human rights law
• understand the difference between legal, political and ethical perspectives on human rights
• explain the main philosophical challenges of the human rights discourse
• apply these philosophical challenges to current human rights issues
• understand and apply the concepts, methods and techniques of philosophical reflection on human rights law as a condition for a decent transnational legal and political order.

column1: In this course we will engage with the work of the well-known, but often misunderstood media philosopher Marshall McLuhan. We will read and engage with the three theses that he develops throughout his work - the extension thesis, the environmental thesis, and the anti-content thesis - as well as how these theses have influenced ways of thinking and talking about media in both popular as well as scientific discourses.
One missed session (lecture or seminar) can be compensated for with an extra written assignment on the content/topics addressed in the missed session.
Only one session can be compensated for in this way. More than one missed session means that the student will not be able to complete the course.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>At the end of the course students will:

column2: • Be familiar with the main suppositions and aims of media-ecological approaches and how they relate to other philosophical approaches to media that have influenced contemporary studies of media and communication;
• Understand the importance of media ecological approaches, and their use as well as limitations for media and communication research;
• Present a well-reasoned argument using concepts from media ecology

• Engage in media-ecological discourse through a short written analysis of one (or two) of its central concepts/theses, as well as in a written essay about a contemporary topic addressed through the lens of media ecological concepts and arguments.

column1: The course Methodology of Management Science focused on the selection of appropriate research methods for the scientific analysis of managerial issues. This Philosophy of Science course not only addresses deeper philosophical questions of how scientific research as a human activity may track the truth about ‘organisational reality’, but also has the aim of providing a conceptual apparatus to understand and evaluate the assumptions and truth claims of the many different theories that exist in the field of management. Management is an interdisciplinary field, and therefore harbours different theories that explain management reality using different concepts and relying on very different assumptions. Sometimes theories in management even give incompatible accounts of the same phenomenon. For both researchers and future managers it is important to be able to make a reasoned choice between the theories that apply to a specific phenomenon. This course not only seeks to provide students with the conceptual apparatus that is relevant in choosing between different theoretical perspectives, but also aims to develop the critical abilities of students to analyse and evaluate theories in management.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The principal objective of this course is to equip students for evaluating and choosing between the many different theories in the field management. Questions that will be addressed during the course include:

column2: • What is the difference between theories and concepts, on the one hand, and facts and empirical research on the other?
• To what extent can and should theories in social science be based on facts and empirical research?
• Should there be room for concepts and theories that do not reduce to facts and observations?
• If we accept non-empirical concepts and theories in social science, how do we establish their validity?
• What are the assumptions of theories in management, and to what extent are these assumptions scientifically acceptable?
• Should we look only at behaviour in social science, or do human intentions also matter in explaining social reality?
• To what extent can social science be value free?
• Can social science say something sensible about normative questions, or should social scientists remain silent about normative issues?

column1: After completing this course, the student has developed the following skills:
Analytical thinking, Argumentation, Theory choice, Academic integrity, Academic writing skills.</body>

column1: Although ignorance is the engine of science, turning general, philosophical wonder into a specific, well-defined research problem, is a very complex, demanding skill, that one can and should actually acquire. Building on insights from the history and philosophy of science, this course discusses and illustrates several methods to define and re(de)fine research problems stepwise, and invites students to reflect critically and creatively about the prerequisites, the powers and the limits of problem solving in both their own discipline and in interdisciplinary contexts.

column1: This course addresses some of the amazingly rich and fascinating questions that pertain both to philosophy and to war. Why do people wage war? Is war an essential attribute of human nature or is it a cultural phenomenon? How were military strategists influenced by their intellectual environment? How has military thought been influenced by the reality of military conflict? How has thinking about war been related to more general concepts about biological evolution, system theory, and game theory? What is the relation between politics and war? When and why do soldiers kill? How will warfare in the future be different from past and present warfare? How will ecological change affect future warfare? How will developments in artificial intelligence influence future warfare? The course starts with a general conceptual introduction and subsequently tackles military thinking from the seventeenth to the twenty-first century. The course consists of eight sessions, each session is devoted to a particular theme.
1. Nature, Importance, and Causes of War: Biological Evolution, Causal Feedback Loops, and Game Theory (12 February).
2. Military Strategy, Game Theory and Contract Theory: Pieter de la Court, Hobbes and Spinoza (19 February).
3. War and Politics: Carl von Clausewitz on war as the continuation of politics with other means (26 February).
4. War and Biological Evolution: Herbert Spencer and the Paradox of War
5. War and the Psychological Reasons for Killing: Sigmund Freud and Dave Grossman (11 March).
6. The End of the Cold War — the End of History? Francis Fukuyama and Samual P. Huntington (18 March)
7. The Future of War 1: Max Brosig and Jan Selby on war and the impact of climate change (25 March).
8. The Future of War 2: James Johnson and Nick Bostrom on war and artificial intelligence (1 April).

The course is open to all students who follow the Master Philosophy, including students who follow the tracks ‘Continental Philosophy and its History’, ‘Philosophy, Politics, Economics’, students who have opted for neither of the two tracks, and Research Master students.

The standard workload for this course is 3.75 EC; students who need 5 EC rather then 3.75 EC are welcome as well, they write an additional essay of 1.500 words; students who need 7 EC rather then 3.75 EC write an additional essay of 4.000 words. For the topic of the essay, please contact the teacher.

Eight sessions, on Friday 2:00-3:45 PM, 13 February-5 April 2018, Campus ‘Woudenstein’, Burgemeester Oudlaan 50, 3062 PA Rotterdam; see Canvas for the room. In course week 9 the students prepare for the examination in course week 10. Examination: Wednesday 18:30-21:30 15 April 2020. Resit: Friday 9:30-12:30 10 July 2020.
All literature can be downloaded from the course site on Canvas.

Participation in the classes is mandatory, but you are free too skip one session. For each additional session, please hand in an additional mini-essay. This mini-essay will be used to replace your answer to the question in the examination for which you have received the highest mark.

column1: <body>As sessile organisms, plants must be able to interpret and respond to their environment to grow and survive. They also live on a different time scale than animals, and even though their life is highly complex and often surprising, most of it is invisible (or still unknown) to humans. This course will therefore teach you the basics of plant biology, including plant structure and morphology, metabolism, reproduction, genetics, evolution and systematics. The main goal of this course is to remove all vestiges of zoocentrism from your mindset, giving you the tools to appreciate the uniqueness and specificities of the Plant Kingdom. You will be able to (i) distinguish the plants from other life forms, (ii) understand how a plant is structured, and which modifications have evolved to cope with the different terrestrial environments, (iii) describe the different parts of a plant by using appropriate botanical terms, (iv) discover why plants are the life sources for food and oxygen for all organisms on Earth, (v) understand the significance of the diplobiontic life cycle of plants, and (vi) appreciate the intricate biochemical and signalling networks of plants, including those of photosynthesis, hormone action and communication with other plants and organisms. Finally, the students will be introduced to the richness of plant diversity resulting from eons of evolution, and to enter a natural area and distinguish the plants encountered as being either Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms or Angiosperms. The course will be supported by extra activities, such as a visit to a botanical garden.</body>

column1: This course highlights the pivotal role of plants on our lives on one side, and the importance of sustainable agriculture in the food production sector on the other side. The first part of the course aims at integrating descriptive knowledge of plant anatomy and morphology with biochemical and genetic mechanisms, in order to study functional processes ranging from seed germination to flowering and fruit set. It also focuses on the study of plant processes - how plants grow, develop and function as they interact with their physical (abiotic) and living (biotic) environments. Based on this acquired knowledge, the second part of the course will focus on agro-ecology and sustainable agriculture in order to give the students an overview about the current systems of plant production and the development of novel sustainable farming systems, from soil management to fertilisation, and from the application of pesticides/herbicides to the use of GMOs. During the course, up-to-date case studies will be presented in order to illustrate how the knowledge of plant ecophysiology and agro-ecology can be a useful tool to cope with increasing environmental and societal issues, such as climate change, food production, sustainable agriculture and environmental pollution.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course, the students will:
1. Be acquainted with the molecular mechanisms and the physiological processes that
shape and regulate plant life. This includes:

column5: Photosynthesis – light and ‘dark’ reactions.
Respiration and lipid metabolism
Assimilation of inorganic nutrients (N, P, S)

column3: - How plants acquire and transport inorganic and organic materials for growth:

column5: Water balance and transport
Solute transport, translocation in the phloem and photosynthates distribution

column3: - How plants grow and develop throughout their lives:

column5: Embryogenesis: root and shoot apical meristems
Seed dormancy, germination and seedling establishment
Vegetative growth: leaf development, shoot branching and architecture, root
Control of flowering and floral development
Signals and signal transduction: hormones and plant development.
Tropisms: growth in response to directional stimuli.
Plant senescence and plant death

column3: - How plants interact with their external environment:

column5: Biotic interactions
Abiotic environmental stress

column3: 2. Discover what is new in plant physiology.
Like most areas of biology, plant physiology is
experiencing an explosion of new discoveries and new ideas. We will discuss some of the
new topics in plant physiology and why they are considered important.
3. Understand that plant physiology relates to other fields in biology.
be plant physiologists. For this course to be valuable to you, you must understand how plant
physiology interconnects with agricultural, forestry, environmental science, genetics, the
health sciences, and other fields. Throughout the course, connections between plant
physiology and other areas of knowledge will be emphasized.
4. Focus on how plant physiology will shape the future.
As students, you must consider the
future and your role in it. Plant biotechnology is putting plants to many new uses and
improving them for old ones. Plants can now be used to grow plastics and fuels, to remove
toxic wastes from soils, and to produce vaccines and drugs. Agriculture and forestry practices
have been altered by new crop varieties that resist stress, pathogens, herbicides, and postharvest
losses. These developments in plant biotechnology are derived from knowledge of
plant physiology and plant genetics. As scientists, business people, teachers, consumers,
voters, and parents, you must contribute to intelligent decisions about how plants should be
used to improve the human condition. To prepare you for this, we will discuss the role of
plant physiology in the future throughout the course.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89797,2019,Plasticity of the Human,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle', 'dr. S van Tuinen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate the relation between man and world in terms of the ‘plasticity of the human’. Today a key concept at the intersection between medicine, design and politics, plasticity is the center-piece of the neurosciences, where it is used to describe the way in which the brain molds itself, developing its own history and historicity beyond genetic predetermination. But it also has a long philosophical history, from its invention by Goethe to Hegel, Nietzsche and Freud, in which it constitutes the transformative continuity between nature and history and between the neuronal and the mental. Plasticity thus raises a challenge for traditional humanistic ideas about the good life: according to what criteria and ends do we actively and passively produce ourselves, and thus also design and compose our social life, our brains, and our planet? Or as Friedrich Nietzsche puts it: How do we become who we are? Starting from a recuperation of the age-old philosophical problem of habit, an exploration of this question will take us to question the ends of man, the nature of history, the malleability of capitalist society, transformations of power and work, and ultimately questions of what to do with the brain and the earth.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Governments try to deal with complex issues, like flood protection, regeneration of urban neighborhoods, and the care for the young and elderly citizens. The context of these issues is often complex and dynamic. If contexts change, the issues changes. The straight forward and top down  implementation of a policy programs very often fail as many cases show. l. Policy initiatives and policy programs than evaporate without acceptable results. Where and why do governments end up in this kinds of inertia? However, other cases show the opposite. Where and why have other governments been able to deal with changing conditions in a more appropriate way and even use ‘the coincidences of change’ to achieve desired results? Why has policy innovation been realized?

This core course of the master in Public Administration Rotterdam elaborates why policies mainly based on political and governmental desires without a systematic understanding of the complex context will often not solve the issue it is dealing with. We clarify how and why supply-oriented policy approaches create all kinds of implementation deficits. In order to deal effectively with complex issues policy makers have to increase their understanding of the complex contexts of issues. The course helps students to make system analysis, based on several theoretical approaches of complexity. Central theoretical concepts are co-evolution, feedback and self-organizing capacities

Successful implementation urges for the &nbsp;connection of the development of policy programs with the real life worlds of citizens and semi public and private sector companies. We present an implementation oriented design of innovative policy programs. The coproduction of public and private organizations together with citizens, NGO’s and knowledge institutes can be improved by process design. Vital networks and chains are needed for effective process design.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The module presents a complex system perspective on governance environments and policy development and implementation processes. Policy processes evolves by positive and negative feedback, by co-evolution of processes and interactions in its context and by self-organizing capacities.

• The module increases your understanding of complexity and the inherent challenges in governing complex governance processes. What explanations does complexity theory generate for success and failure of large-scale policy programs? As a result you  will increase your capacities to apply complex system analysis.

• The module will also increase your abilities to cope with complexity. We will elaborate several implementation-oriented approaches for designing and redesigning policies: the formation of joint action in policy chains, the ability to organize reversed chain approaches starting bottom-up and coproduction in complex systems and networks.
• Elaborating modern governance and public sector innovation approaches: facilitating, smart small scale interventions, coproduction and meta-governance strategies in complex systems
• Applying methods and techniques for analyzing policy chains, public sector innovation and meta-governance
• High quality reflections on strength and weaknesses of the approaches presented.

column1: <body>The course will focus on the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health which typically are non-standard markets with a lot of government intervention. Questions that will be addressed are:

column2: • What are the main instruments for policy makers to improve the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health and what do we know about the effects?
• How can the government stimulate optimal investment in human capital or in health capital?

column1: This first course in the Politics & Society specialisation familiarises students with the sociological study of politics, focusing on social patterns in public attitudes and political behaviour. How can we understand social differences in support for various value orientations, ideologies, and political parties? And how can we explain social inequalities in political trust and political involvement, both in the formal political domain and in non-institutional politics? There has been a marked decline in Western societies from the 1960s onwards in encompassing political ideologies and the political salience of classic group identities such as classes and religions – a process often referred to as individualisation. This does, however, not imply that value conflicts, voting behaviour, and participation in social movements are no longer socially shaped. On the contrary: old social fault lines have given way to new ones. Systematically combining theories from both sociology and political science with findings from empirical research, this course addresses the contemporary political relevance of these social cleavages. What are their present-day implications? Which groups currently clash over which issues, why is this the case, and how is this related to support for political parties? How can we interpret social differences in anti-immigrant sentiments, political trust, voter turnout, and political protest? And how are these political attitudes and behaviours influenced by online and offline social networks?

column1: This course is an introduction to political economy. The basic premise of this course is that political actors follow their own self interest. As a consequence the government cannot be considered as a single benevolent actor as is typically assumed in Public Finance. Instead interactions between different political actors determine the outcome of the political process. In particular we will consider the incentives of politicians, voters, media, interest groups and bureaucrats. We will see how they interact and determine the outcome and efficiency of the political process.

We will use standard mathematical analysis and game-theoretic modeling to analyze the interactions of political actors. Thus students should be familiar with the basic concepts of optimization and game theory. Exercises will complement the lecture to give students the opportunity to apply the insights and practice the tools encountered in the lecture.</body>

column1: This course aims, first of all, to explain the basic organisational framework of modern states by highlighting its key components. Secondly, we will identify and analyse the factors that determine what policymakers can and cannot do. This relates to the institutions in which they are embedded, the social organisations and policy networks on which they depend, and the cultural legacies within which they operate. Thirdly, the course sets out to enhance students’ understanding of the fundamental transformations that are currently unfolding in key political institutions and public policy-making:
1.         The role and place of government and the nation state in modern societies;
2.         How public policies are designed, evaluated and implemented;

This course engages with concrete governance ‘problems’ encountered by states and societies across the world, such as corruption and climate change. Finally, the course will also highlight the role of non-state actors in the policy process.</body>

• Describe the role of a selected number of political institutions in modern states and reflect on their infuence and performance
• Describe how governments design and implement policies
• Reflect on the origins and backgrounds of governmental policies in various policy domains

column1: The theme of this module is the significance and value of democracy in modern politics and administration. That there is such a value inherent to democracy is not self-evident in a world in which crisis- and conflict management and the effective design of policy arrangements seem to demand clear priority. However the democratic process may be organised, there remains a degree of unpredictability in the behaviour and choice of the demos (‘the people’), as history keeps on teaching us.

Within history as well, democracy was never fully accepted. There was always something to criticise, whether this be the lack of competent judgement of the people, the complexity of decision making, the interested self-seeking of the electorate or political parties, short term effect and the degree to which democracy was overwhelmed by media attention and emotion.

At the same time, political thinkers of the past were fascinated by the idea of self-rule; the notion that given an adequate organisational design, such a design might enable human beings to be genuinely autonomous and independent. Important ideas such as sovereignty, power, social contract, and even the idea of administration itself, were developed in this regard, occasionally also in opposition to the ‘plebeian threat’.

Nonetheless, it cannot be denied that in the course of time, gradually and often operating against the tide, a sense of politics and administration appeared whose principle is self-rule and that often stands opposed to a technocratic idea of the political order. In this course the various stages within this development are identified and characterised in relation to current challenges of politics and administration. Different developments in thinking about democracy are discussed and their institutional realisation in administrative practices is explored. This means that not only the basic ideas and mechanisms underlying modern representative democracy are addressed, but also more recent innovations that aim to enlarge representative democracy with institutions for direct citizen participation. Finally, the challenges of democracy beyond the nation-state in the global realm are explored based on a conceptual understanding of the history of democracy. These themes form the basis of the assignments carried out during the biweekly seminars.

The lectures and seminars in this course are fully integrated. The seminars are used to develop basic historical and philosophical skills that enable students to reflect on the contents of the lectures and thereby work towards a fresh understanding of the character of modern democratic politics and the history of the representative state in its current form. Attending the lectures and staying ahead with the course readings is absolutely essential in order to carry out the seminar assignments and prepare for the individual portfolio assignment.</body>

column1: ""And what should they know of England who only England know?” (Rudyard Kipling, auteur van The Jungle Book)

Politics is the process by which groups reach and enforce binding decisions. Power is the currency of politics. To survive, political systems need to force their members to do what they would not otherwise have done. Notwithstanding globalization, national political systems are still the main place for the legitimate execution of power. At the same time, nations differ widely in their institutions for political decision-making. This allows for comparison: learning more about other countries, and therewith about your own country, classifying characteristics of political systems, analyzing their causes and consequences, applying causal theories to understand the effects of societal and political-institutional change.

This course introduces students to the discipline of empirical political science. After having discussed the main concepts, we will compare and analyze various facets of national political systems. Democratic versus authoritarian systems, political trust, political communication and media, political cleavages, political parties, election rules and voting behavior, parliamentarian versus presidential governments, the structure and function of parliaments, and the role of constitutions and constitutional courts. Looking through the glasses of a political scientist, we seek to answer questions such as the following: Does trust in governments decline and what factors account for trust/distrust? What is the impact of social media on politics? Does globalization lead to new cleavages in society? What factors explain the rise of societal and political populism in Europe and across the globe? How are governments formed? Are coalition governments less stable than single-party governments? Are parliaments willing and able to control governments and are they representative of the electorate?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After passing the course, students are able to

column2: • define major political science concepts
• reproduce major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems
• compare major political characteristics of the Netherlands and a selected number of other political systems along relevant dimensions
• explain causal theories about relationships between characteristics of political systems
• evaluate the validity of causal theories based on existing data
• predict the effect of societal and institutional changes on political phenomena
• evaluate proposals for institutional change based on expected effects on relevant feature of political systems
• develope and defend a position of a political group for negotiating a new constitution
